campaignTrail_temp.candidate_last_name = "Clark"; campaignTrail_temp.running_mate_last_name = "Landrieu"; campaignTrail_temp.jet_data = [{ "nicknames": { "201": "Clark" }, "banner_enabled": true, "https://i.imgur.com/u7iwnFB_d.jpg?maxwidth=520&shape=thumb&fidelity=high" }, "endings_enabled": false, "ending_data": {} } ] function ctsAchievement(achievement, difficultyChecker = true){ if ((difficultyChecker && campaignTrail_temp.difficulty_level_multiplier<=1)||!difficultyChecker){ if(campaignTrail_temp.CTS){ unlockAchievement(achievement); } } } function unlockAchievement(name) { const ach = findAchievementByName(name); if (ach == null) { console.log("There is no achievement with the name '" + name + "'"); return; } if (cheatsActive && ach.cannotBeCheated) { console.log(`Would unlock '${name}' but won't because cheating!`); return; } if (unlockedAch[name] == null) { //alert("ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED: " + name); } showAchievement(name); unlockedAch[name] = ach; localStorage.setItem("unlockedAch", JSON.stringify(unlockedAch)); addAllAchievements(); } function showAchievement(achievementKey) { const achievement = campaignTrail_temp.achievements[achievementKey]; // Create the achievement box const box = document.createElement('div'); Object.assign(box.style, { position: "fixed", bottom: "20px", right: "20px", width: "230px", height: "110px", backgroundColor: "#0A2463", color: "#FFFFFF", border: "2px solid #D4AF37", borderRadius: "8px", padding: "15px", boxShadow: "0 0 10px rgba(10, 36, 99, 0.8)", zIndex: "10000", fontSize: "14px", display: "flex", alignItems: "center", gap: "15px", opacity: "0", transition: "opacity 0.5s ease-in-out", fontFamily: "'Segoe UI', Arial, sans-serif", overflow: "hidden" }); // Stack multiple achievements vertically const existingBoxes = document.querySelectorAll('.achievement-popup'); const offset = existingBoxes.length * 120; box.style.bottom = `${20 + offset}px`; // Achievement image const img = document.createElement('img'); img.src = achievement.image; img.alt = achievementKey; Object.assign(img.style, { width: "80px", height: "80px", objectFit: "contain", border: "1px solid #D4AF37", borderRadius: "4px" }); // Achievement title const title = document.createElement('div'); title.innerHTML = `${achievementKey}`; title.style.textAlign = "center"; title.style.width = "100%"; box.appendChild(img); box.appendChild(title); box.classList.add('achievement-popup'); document.body.appendChild(box); // Fade in setTimeout(() => { box.style.opacity = "1"; }, 10); // Fade out and remove after 4 seconds setTimeout(() => { box.style.opacity = "0"; box.addEventListener('transitionend', () => { box.remove(); adjustPopupPositions(); }); }, 4000); } function adjustPopupPositions() { setTimeout(() => { const boxes = document.querySelectorAll('.achievement-popup'); boxes.forEach((box, index) => { box.style.bottom = `${20 + index * 120}px`; }); }, 10); } updateQuestions(mutationList, observer) { if (answerObject.fields.condition != null) { answer.disabled = !(eval(answerObject.fields.condition)); } } const observer = new MutationObserver(onGameWindowChanged); observer.observe(targetNode, config); e.VPisCandidate = 0; function updateQuestionBanner() { let questionBanner = document.getElementById("campaign_sign"); if console.log("banner change success"); } questionBanner.replaceWith(img); } // Initial update updateQuestionBanner(); function tunnel(new_q){ return e.questions_json[e.questions_json.map(f=>f.pk).indexOf(new_q)]; } function swapAnswers(answersArray, targetQuestionId, answerToDisablePk, replacementAnswerPk, fakeQuestionId) { answersArray.forEach(answer => { // Disable original answer by moving it to fake question if (answer.pk === answerToDisablePk && answer.fields.question === targetQuestionId) { answer.fields.question = fakeQuestionId; } // Enable hidden answer by assigning to target question if (answer.pk === replacementAnswerPk) { answer.fields.question = targetQuestionId; } }); } //Clark coloor function switcheroo100() { var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(201) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "Wesley K." e.candidate_json[id].fields.last_name = "Clark" The call won't come."; } else { e.WinPopup = "wes its glup shitto, i lost"; e.LosePopup = "glup shitto its wes, i lost"; } //achievement checks //help Lamont if (e.noCounter == 7 && Win > 5 && (ans == 5184 || ans == 20755)) { ctsAchievement("A Hero Made, A Rival Unmade"); } //mid healthcare reform if (ans == 22483) { ctsAchievement("Breaking from the Lineage"); } //repeal DADT if (ans == 24726 || ans == 22475 || ans == 24700 || ans == 24713) { ctsAchievement("Ancestral Curses"); } //midterm sweep if (e.noCounter == 7 && Win > 7){ ctsAchievement("Conquistador"); } //iran war if (ans == 25094) { ctsAchievement("When Ares Walks Among Men"); } //cheney heart attack if (ans == 24331) { ctsAchievement("Pulse Torn by Thunder"); } //kill osama if (ans == 24183) { ctsAchievement("Cast to the Underworld"); } //hillary econ if (ans == 255121 || ans == 22514 || ans == 22562) { ctsAchievement("Bow to Moira"); } //bernie econ if (ans == 255124 || ans == 22565 || ans == 23728) { ctsAchievement("Chronos Denied"); } //boost santorum if (ans == 24571){ ctsAchievement("Order & Anarchy"); } //4way debate if (Dem == 5 && Neo > 8 && e.player_answers.includes(24571)){ ctsAchievement("Chaos Agents"); } } function updateHistoricalData(newVpTable, newHexColors, newNames, newEvs, newPvs, newPvps) { vpTableHistorical = newVpTable; HistHexcolour = newHexColors; HistName = newNames; HistEV = newEvs; HistPV = newPvs; HistPVP = newPvps; } vpTable = { "Wesley K. Clark" : "Mary Landrieu", "⠀Ron Paul" : "Gary Johnson", "⠀Randall Terry" : "Stephen Broden", } newHistHexcolour13=["#742b2b","#4b7db6","#c9b34c","#afb7e3"]; newHistName13=["⠀Dick Cheney","⠀Wesley K. Clark","⠀Ron Paul","⠀Randall Terry"]; newHistEV13=[450,88,0,0]; newHistPV13=["76,349,206","49,534,833","3,117,218","2,041,414"]; newHistPVP13=["58.3%","37.8%","2.4%","1.5%"]; function onGameWindowChangeCandidates() { const resultsTableHolder = document.getElementById("overall_details_container"); if(!resultsTableHolder || resultsTableHolder.classList.contains("done")) { return; } resultsTableHolder.classList.add("done"); const resultsTable = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[3].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTable.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTable.children[i]; let name = row.firstChild.innerText; row.insertCell(1); if(name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); console.log("name is:" + name) } if(i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTable[name]; } } const resultsTableHistorical = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[5].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTableHistorical.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTableHistorical.children[i]; let name = row.childNodes[1].innerText; row.insertCell(1); if(name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); } if(i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTableHistorical[name]; } } // Add CSS to increase row spacing const styleElem = document.createElement('style'); styleElem.textContent = ` #overall_details_container table tr { line-height: 1.125; /* Adjust line height as needed */ } `; document.head.appendChild(styleElem); } const gameWindowNode = document.getElementById("game_window"); const candidateWatcherConfig = { attributes: true, childList: true, subtree: true }; const candidateObserver = new MutationObserver(onGameWindowChangeCandidates); candidateObserver.observe(gameWindowNode, candidateWatcherConfig); function getTooltips(str) { let matches = []; tooltipList.forEach((tooltip, index) => { // Adjust the regex to match searchString potentially surrounded by “ and followed by optional punctuation let regex = new RegExp(`(?<=\\b|\\s|^|“)${tooltip.searchString}(?=[.,;!?]?\\b|\\s|”|$)`, 'g'); let match; while ((match = regex.exec(str)) !== null) { matches.push({ start: match.index + (match[0].startsWith('“') ? 1 : 0), // Adjust for potential starting “ end: match.index + match[0].length - (match[0].endsWith('”') ? 1 : 0) - (match[2] ? 1 : 0), tooltipIndex: index }); } }); // Sort by starting position; if two start at the same position, longer match comes first matches.sort((a, b) => a.start - b.start || b.end - b.start - (a.end - a.start)); // Filter out overlaps for (let i = 0; i < matches.length - 1; ) { if (matches[i + 1].start < matches[i].end) { matches.splice(i + 1, 1); // Remove the next match since it overlaps } else { i++; // Move to next match } } return matches; } function applyTooltips(str) { const matches = getTooltips(str); let result = ''; let lastIndex = 0; matches.forEach(match => { const tooltip = tooltipList[match.tooltipIndex]; result += str.slice(lastIndex, match.start); result += `${tooltip.searchString}${tooltip.explanationText}`; lastIndex = match.end; }); result += str.slice(lastIndex); // Add the remainder of the original string return result; } function applyTooltipsToObject(obj) { for (let key in obj) { if (typeof obj[key] === 'string') { obj[key] = applyTooltips(obj[key]); } else if (typeof obj[key] === 'object') { applyTooltipsToObject(obj[key]); // Recursive call } } } applyTooltipsToObject(campaignTrail_temp.questions_json); applyTooltipsToObject(campaignTrail_temp.answers_json); applyTooltipsToObject(campaignTrail_temp.answer_feedback_json); // constructs endings based on header and pages construct = (a = 1) => { e.page = e.page + a < e.pages.length ? e.page + a : 0 let html = e.header; html += e.pages[e.page] + "
"; if (e.page > 0) { html += `` } if (e.page < e.pages.length - 1) { html += `` } for (i in e.executable) { if (e.executable[i][0] == e.page) { e.executable[i][1](); } } if (e.image == true) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0] if (candImg) { candImg.remove() console.log("TRYING"); $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` text-align:left; width: 72%; height:71%; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; overflow: auto; ` console.log("RESULTS UPDATED"); } }, 10) else if (e.image) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0]; if (candImg) { candImg.src = e.image; console.log("TRYING"); $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` text-align:left; width: 72%; height:71%; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; overflow: auto; ` console.log("RESULTS UPDATED"); } }, 10) return html; } endingConstructor = (a = 1) => { $("#final_results_description")[0].innerHTML = construct(a); } // ENDINGS -- this is slightly more reliable than the ending code method e.multiple_endings = true; e.header = "

error

"; e.pages = ["

This is an error handler

"]; e.page = 0; endingPicker = (out, totv, aa, quickstats) => { //out = "win", "loss", or "tie" for your candidate //totv = total votes in entire election //aa = all final overall results data //quickstat = relevant data on candidate performance (format: your candidate's electoral vote count, your candidate's popular vote share, your candidate's raw vote total) /* e.header = "

" e.pages = ["

", "

"] */ function getStateNamesMap() { const stateNamesMap = {}; campaignTrail_temp.states_json.forEach((state) => { stateNamesMap[state.pk] = state.fields.name; }); return stateNamesMap; } // Function to map candidate PKs to their names for better readability function getCandidateNamesMap() { const candidateNamesMap = {}; campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json.forEach((candidate) => { candidateNamesMap[candidate.pk] = candidate.fields.last_name; }); return candidateNamesMap; } // Function to get the percentage of votes per candidate in each state function getVotePercentages() { if (!e.player_answers.includes(21146) && !e.player_answers.includes(22333) && !e.player_answers.includes(22390)) { return; } const votePercentages = {}; campaignTrail_temp.final_state_results.forEach((result) => { const statePK = result.state; votePercentages[statePK] = result.result.map((candidateResult) => ({ candidate: candidateResult.candidate, percentage: candidateResult.percent * 100, })); }); return votePercentages; } function campaignSummary() { const stateNamesMap = getStateNamesMap(); const candidateNamesMap = getCandidateNamesMap(); const votes = getVotePercentages(); // Initialize boolean flags let santorumWinsAlabama = false; let gravelWinsAlaska = false; for (const statePK in votes) { const stateName = stateNamesMap[statePK] || `Unknown State (${statePK})`; console.log(`State: ${stateName}`); console.log(`Vote Percentages:`); let maxVotes = 0; let candidateMax = ""; votes[statePK].forEach((voteData) => { const candidateName = candidateNamesMap[voteData.candidate] || `Candidate ${voteData.candidate}`; console.log(` ${candidateName}: ${voteData.percentage.toFixed(2)}%`); if (voteData.percentage > maxVotes) { maxVotes = voteData.percentage; candidateMax = candidateName; } }); // Check conditions if (stateName === "Alabama" && candidateMax === "Santorum") { santorumWinsAlabama = true; console.log(`Santorum won Alabama!`); } if (stateName === "Alaska" && candidateMax === "Gravel") { gravelWinsAlaska = true; console.log(`Gravel won Alaska!`); } console.log("-----------------------------"); } console.log(`Santorum wins Alabama: ${santorumWinsAlabama}`); console.log(`Gravel wins Alaska: ${gravelWinsAlaska}`); // Return the results if needed by other functions return { santorumWinsAlabama, gravelWinsAlaska }; } const campaignResults = campaignSummary(); changeState = (statePK, candidateId, amount = true) => { if (!e.player_answers.includes(21146) && !e.player_answers.includes(22333) && !e.player_answers.includes(22390)) { return; } const state = e.states_json[e.states_json.map(f=>f.pk).indexOf(statePK)]; const electoralVoteCount = state.fields.electoral_votes; const sMI = e.final_state_results.map(f=>f.state).indexOf(statePK); // find candidate's results in the state const candidateResults = e.final_state_results[sMI].result[ e.final_state_results[sMI].result.map(f=>f.candidate).indexOf(candidateId) ]; let change; if (Neo > 7) { // Only proceed if Neo score is above 7 const winner = e.final_state_results[sMI].result[0].candidate; if (amount === true) { // clear existing EV allocations e.final_state_results[sMI].result.forEach((a, i, arr) => { arr[i].electoral_votes = 0; }); // give candidate all EVs candidateResults.electoral_votes = electoralVoteCount; change = electoralVoteCount; } else { // clear existing EV allocations e.final_state_results[sMI].result.forEach((a, i, arr) => { arr[i].electoral_votes = 0; }); e.final_state_results[sMI].result[0].electoral_votes = electoralVoteCount - amount; // give candidate specified EVs candidateResults.electoral_votes = amount; change = amount; } const candidateOverall = e.final_overall_results[ e.final_overall_results.map(f=>f.candidate).indexOf(candidateId) ]; const winnerOverall = e.final_overall_results[ e.final_overall_results.map(f=>f.candidate).indexOf(winner) ]; candidateOverall.electoral_votes += change; winnerOverall.electoral_votes -= change; } } const { santorumWinsAlabama, gravelWinsAlaska } = campaignResults; if (!e.initDC) { e.initDC = true; if (jonked === 0) { if (e.player_answers.includes(21146) || e.player_answers.includes(22333) || e.player_answers.includes(22390)) { if (Neo > 7 && Neo <= 9 && !santorumWinsAlabama) { changeState(1000, 202, 2); //2 Alabama for Santorum } else if (Neo > 9) { if (!santorumWinsAlabama && !gravelWinsAlaska) { changeState(1000, 202, 2); //2 Alabama for Santorum changeState(1044, 203, 1); //1 Alaska for Gravel } else if (santorumWinsAlabama && !gravelWinsAlaska) { changeState(1044, 203, 1); //1 Alaska for Gravel } else if (!santorumWinsAlabama && gravelWinsAlaska) { changeState(1000, 202, 2); //2 Alabama for Santorum } } } } else { return; } } e.pages = [] e.header = ""; e.executable = [] //achievements if (quickstats[0] >= 270){ ctsAchievement("Go Wes Go"); } if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 8){ ctsAchievement("Weathered the Storm"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 7){ ctsAchievement("Unmask a False Prophet"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 6){ ctsAchievement("Mortals vs the Divine"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 5){ ctsAchievement("Psychological Clarity"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 4 && Messiah == 1){ ctsAchievement("Messiah"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 4){ ctsAchievement("Heroism"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 3){ ctsAchievement("Kingslayer"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 2){ ctsAchievement("Mirror Image"); }else if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Dem == 1){ ctsAchievement("Absolute Hierarchy"); } if (e.player_answers.includes(24162) || e.player_answers.includes(22610)){ ctsAchievement("Titanomachy Reborn"); } if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Fred == 0 && Econ == 0 && Lehman == 0){ ctsAchievement("Harbinger of Hades"); } if (quickstats[0] >= 270 && Lehman == 1 && Econ == 4){ ctsAchievement("Vanguard of the Revolution"); } //LANDSLIDE DEFEAT if (aa[0].electoral_votes < 270 && Dem > 0 && War == 1) { // ww3 loss - e.pages.push(`

Icarus

Falling—it was agony.

A rapid plunge into the abyss, and not one hand reached out to save him. Icarus could only imagine how he became the protagonist of such a tale. His once-celebrated achievements quickly dissolved into oblivion, while critics from every corner emerged to seize the pen writing this story.

Those who once lifted him now parrot the same words: he flew too close to the sun. As if ambition alone explained his fall—as if striving too far, too fast made him some reckless overachiever, doomed by pride. They hope to sidestep the wrath of his defeat by washing their hands of guilt as if they are innocent victims. His loyal second hand began to fly as far away from him as she could.

Cowards, all of them.

The painful truth is that they will likely get their wish and find future opportunities to squander. Outsiders drew their conclusions. They say Icarus was too cautious and too wasteful by squandering rare opportunities and charging into battle, lacking those on the ground to cheer him on. They argue that he might have triumphed if he had pursued bolder conquests and chased grander spoils. It was a tug of war between those wanting more and those fearing it was too much.

The prevailing narrative concluded that Icarus failed to please either. The game was over, and as the figure of Icarus fell to the floor Clark's vision snapped to reality.

As his office was swiftly dissected for his successor to paint anew, Clark looked out toward the streets of Washington. Unsure whether to feel regret or believe that he did everything he could. He turned away, hoping to move on from this mess. The diorama representing his journey was soon tossed in a box and shipped alongside him.

His story had concluded, and Clark no longer cared to ponder alternate tales. He had lost the war. And soldiers on the losing side are rarely remembered as anything more.

Judas

Icarus sat nearly jealous of all the attention he garnered; why him? What was so special about this individual? Abyss

Olympus has fallen; there was no denying it. Well, before the battle began, it was undeniable that there would be no victory at the end of the tunnel.

Doors were being kicked in, families were left penniless, stability abroad had collapsed, the defenses of Olympus were weakened, and Icarus was dying.

Sitting on his throne one last time, he looked up at the art on his walls. The judgmental faces of his most valued predecessors haunted him. He tore their portraits down; behind them were his abode's broken and tattered walls. There was no more time to lament his failures; the bells were ringing, and it was time for him to take flight.

The ground shook as he pushed forward through the halls of Olympus. Finally ready to soar into the sunset, well he hoped as he looked far out into the distance, he saw it. The Storm was here.

Icarus took flight, knowing he wouldn't land gracefully. He met the storm face to face. Lightning struck Icarus deep in the heart, sending him plummeting from the clouds. As he descended into the abyss, so did Olympus; his fate was tied to it and was forever lost.

`) // idk how to add playlists but to do that you create a new playlist in code1 with just that song and put changePlaylist(nameOfYourEndingPlaylist) right here //e.image = "" e.executable.push([0, (() => { e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/Ui4PWNZ.gif'; const audio = document.getElementById("audio"); if (audio) audio.loop = true; })]); const cheneyWin = new Playlist(); const cheneyWinSong = new Song( "Sweet Dreams", "Marilyn Manson", "https://i.imgur.com/8UjJ7XG.gif", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/jsAmOj6zQTTuRv1X2mhC9fP0Xalr8Riq" ); cheneyWin.addSong(cheneyWinSong); changePlaylist(cheneyWin); } else if (quickstats[0] >= 269 && Dem == 8) { // win against cheney no nukes e.pages.push(`

Passionate Stand Off

Fear gripped the streets of Olympus as the helpless populace Icarus had sworn to protect found themselves torn from their homes and families. The Storm had arrived and set out to dismantle his entire domain without mercy; it was unstoppable. The pillars that once upheld the city trembled and fell, and rooftops were ripped from their moorings and cast into the sky like leaves in a gale.

From his perch above the chaos, Icarus stared into a sea of panic while the earth beneath him cracked open. The city's defenses buckled and broke after the Storm's relentless assault. The prophets had been right. This was no ordinary foe.

Tornadoes carved through neighborhoods, and shattered debris rained from the heavens, piercing ceilings and hope alike. At that moment, Icarus knew there was no backup coming. No cavalry. No retreat. He would have to face this tempest alone if he wanted to save them.

He couldn't afford caution. This called for something reckless, something bold. It's a final gambit. A hail mary. It was the only way to prove them all wrong. Icarus drew his cards, spread his wings, and took off into the sky. The resistance was fierce, but he had something the Storm could never manifest: the heart and soul of the people who threw their faith behind him.

Driven by the hope still burning in those below, he pierced the Storm, tearing open a sanctuary in its center. A calm eye where the people could find refuge. The Storm got its wish to tear his home to shreds, but it failed to take his people, and soon, the Storm would pass by, failing to carry the soul of Olympus with it. Icarus knew he'd need to rebuild, but he was grateful that he'd be the one to raise the walls with a gentler vision.

55.7510° N, 37.6176° E

Media Contact:

Erin Delgado, Press Secretary

press@hrc.alt | (202) 555-0143

Moscow, Russia

55.7510° N, 37.6176° E

11:38 MSK, November 6, 2008

Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin quietly made his way back and forth across the pool, engrossed in the silence of the cold water. Outside of the pool, there were 11 million Muscovites clamoring amongst each other. Outside of the pool, there was the weight of his duties as prime minister of the largest country on the planet, the weight of being one of the most powerful men in the world. Outside of the pool, far from Moscow, there was a war going on.

Inside the pool, there was only the water and Putin. He loved swimming, absolutely adored it in a way that he adored little else. Physically, it gave him a chance to test the mettle of his 56-year-old body, to force it to collaborate with him. Mentally, it gave him a chance to shut out the outside voices, to focus solely upon his own thoughts. It was the latter half of the equation that was more important at the moment, as he needed all of the mental firepower possible to answer the biggest riddle there was: America.

At the moment, he was about halfway through untying the Gordian knot, but he could not, for the life of him, wrap his head around figuring out how America had succeeded as much as it had when its residents were so uniformly fucking stupid. On American election night, he had gone to bed at the normal time, expecting that he’d wake up knowing what the country’s fate would be. Then, the next day, he had found out just how stupid the American system was. The election had deadlocked? There was going to be a contingent election? Or maybe there actually wasn’t? Nobody was quite sure? Nobody knew who was going to win? He had a set of apparatchiks come into his office, brilliant young men and women who had relentlessly studied America their whole lives to the point of even travelling in it extensively, to explain what exactly had gripped the American political system. None of them could explain it.

Putin felt that nobody quite exemplified the concept of American stupidity quite like President Clark, the general. Putin had read the briefings: objectively speaking, the man was a genius, and more than that, a competent genius who could lead with authority. A man that smart, that capable, should have been able to have the great levels of the world’s superpower turned to suit his will in no time at all. Instead, here he was, engaged in petty squabbles with a Republican party who, if Putin was being honest, seemed like a gang of corrupt goons. Now, in the face of a national crisis, rather than handling it like the man who had brought down Milosevic, he instead was having a meltdown, getting emotional on live television, ranting like a lunatic. It was unfitting. The only reason for a man that great to have been brought down had to be the eternal stupidity of the American nation. It was the only explanation that made sense.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/LjTsc8R.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 1) { // Feingold supremacy e.pages.push(`

Rolling Stone: March 2009 Issue

"The Admiral Who Said No"

By Evan Wright

"They wanted a war. They wanted a provocation, I wasn't gonna sign my name on it and they weren't going to get it.'" — Adm. William Fallon (Ret.)

When the president assembled a conclave of the brightest military minds to help him in his crusade against Iran, the man once dubbed "The Boss of the Middle East" stormed out like a burning building, and now, in a similar fashion, he sits with us to tell the tale.

Admiral William Fallon, the four-star general who once oversaw the U.S. Central Command, never took glee from entering the spotlight. But now, after his abrupt resignation in February, just weeks into the McCain administration, he's breaking his silence. "The next catastrophe the American people deserve to know about ahead of time."

THE WAR THAT ALMOST WAS

When John McCain took the oath of office in January, the transition from campaign rhetoric to Oval Office restraint was swift and jarring. While the economy continued its derailment from the tracks, instead of dealing with the immediate problem, he turned his interest toward one topic in classified meetings: Iran.

"They were like zombies," Fallon says, straight-faced. "Not in a strategic way, but driven by some morale crusade. Iran wasn't just a problem; it was a dragon to be slain."

Fallon, a seasoned naval officer with decades of experience and rooms filled with vouchers ready to stand up beside him, explained it was as if it were a movie. "The intel was bare bones. The scenarios were worst-case by default. The confidence was astounding, and for what? Because they were weak? They were anything but weak.

Fallon claimed he made string assertions that were cast aside. He laid out facts, plans, fallout estimates, and a lack of exit strategies. "It was as if I shouted at a wake. The room would quiet until the Vice President said, 'The window is closing.' That's when I realized they were too far gone.

THE FINAL STRAW

The breaking point came during a January 30th meeting in the Situation Room. "We had barely gotten our foot in the door, and they piled papers on our feet. A package of coordinated strikes. This was planned long before the president had announced his intention to run.

By February 5, Fallon had his foot halfway out the door. The public excuse was "philosophical differences." Behind closed doors, it was apparent.

"I told them, 'You're going to destabilize the region over a fantasy told by video games. You want a seasoned resume to bless it? Not happening."

"I told them, 'You're going to blow up the region over a fantasy. And you want my uniform to bless it? Not happening.'"

THE GENERAL VS. THE HAWK

McCain was no stranger to saber-rattling; after all, he outhawked nearly every opponent he faced during his presidential campaign. He started with his infamous "bomb, bomb, bomb Iran" joke, which got the right people in New Hampshire to sink their neighboring state's golden child in favor of a brave confrontational ideology. Then, he shouted about the threat of a new Axis Powers while against Clark.

While teenagers in the Oval Office chatted about raining hellfire over millions of civilians like it was high school gossip, Fallon stood as the adult in the room.

"They weren't looking for a strategy, or a plan, they wanted validation."


Related Stories:
McCain’s Cabinet: Bush era déjà vu?
Is the former president planning on joining CODE PINK protests?
The Party of War Returns: Is diplomacy dead?

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/sqt4uHA.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 1) { // Feingold supremacy e.pages.push(`

Politico: The Blue Wave came, and it swept away McCain's mandate.

Opinion: President John McCain rode into the White House on the economic woes of the Clark Administration. He's a man elected not because what he brought to the table was popular but because the other guy was an idiot.

The complete collapse of the president's mandate proves that. Democrats nationwide ran on four words: "He Killed Social Security." The McCain administration knew this insurmountable task was unpopular, and his trips throughout the states to make the bill to reform the system seem popular only hurt its public view. McCain's refusal to cut taxes as a compromise for the bill eliminated all and any support from the opposition. However, what hurt him most was the collapse of the support within the Republican base. The old folk who relied on Social Security felt uncomfortable with his reforms. Regardless, by the summer of 09, he didn't seem to waver in supporting such a plan.

Public opinion hit a boiling point, but McCain still had the numbers to get what he wanted to be passed. So he ignored the normality of representing the people and forced upon America a "tough pill to swallow." Democrats tried to pull any tricks they could to combat the bill, but they lacked the numbers to stop it, and Republicans sent the bill through. Well, now, here we are. The American people have rejected the McCain administration's pill. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has the numbers to comfortably stalemate whatever McCain may bring from here. It looks like President McCain has accepted the fact that his domestic agenda has been slain and has set his eyes abroad. The redeployment of troops into Iraq and Afghanistan was only the start of McCain's war-hungry agenda.


Politico Coverage
Senator Russ Feingold launched a political action committee to explore the possibility of running for president in the 2012 election.
Senator-elect Charlie Crist announces he will caucus with the Democratic Party.
Governor Dave Freudenthal's gamble on challenging Wyoming Governor term limits paid off, reelected by slim margins.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/1gDIhjc.png'})]) } if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Dem == 1) { // mccain L e.pages.push(`

Reuters: Why John McCain lost the White House

Phoenix (Reuters) - Republican John McCain lost Tuesday's presidential election in an upset at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The veteran Senator, whose poll numbers had surged to astronomical numbers in September, came crashing down by election day.

As the blame game began, analysts on all sides of the aisle were scratching their heads. How could this happen? President Clark had completely crashed his campaign by attacking Senator McCain's service.

Clark's apology for such remarks was equally unpopular and most pathetic. The President's approval rating with veterans had dropped to dangerously low levels.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally tough political environment for Democrats, the Senator's hopes and dreams faded on election night.

Eight years after his original presidential campaign in 2000, Senator McCain often came off as a polished statesman with a respectable record.

But the surprise outcome isn't one without some reasoning. The Senator's selection of Democrat Joe Lieberman had stirred much criticism from his right flank, culminating in the surge of the Reform Party nominee Pat Buchanan.

In a solemn concession speech, Senator McCain reflected on his own mistakes and offered nothing but goodwill to the President.

"This was a difficult campaign but I'm proud of our enthusiastic support," he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in Phoenix. "Now it's time for our nation to heal and I hope all the best for our nation and President Clark."

Republican strategist John Feehery said McCain's choice for Vice President had been the most obvious source to blame for the defeat.

"Senator McCain was often cautioned that a move of picking a running mate from the opposite party would come to this."

The financial crisis that erupted in September, followed by President Clark's remarks on Face The Nation, had seemingly given McCain an untouchable lead. Gallup polls in late September showed the Senator 15 points ahead of Clark.

OVERCONFIDENCE, BAD OPTICS

It's unavoidable that at least some reason McCain lost comes down simply to Joe Lieberman's selection. A pro-choice Democrat with a strong gay rights record was too much for the Republican base to consider.

He championed national security concerns and a return to a respectable foreign policy but often neglected the bread and butter issues like abortion. Lieberman only helped double down on these issues, limiting the campaign's range.

The financial crisis also put conservatism as an ideology under much speculation. While President Clark responded calmly and firmly, Senator McCain's proposals didn't go far enough. The offer of tax cuts and reigning in government spending during a crisis and calamity had fallen flat.

Aides of the Clark Administration seem equally bewildered by the outcome.

"It is highly doubtful that anyone will ever have an easier and more advantaged political climate than Senator McCain was given." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top McCain campaign officials say that the outcome also blindsided McCain.

What about Lieberman? To most, McCain's pick for Vice President did nothing to sew ties with the right flank and potentially tanked the veteran Senator's campaign.

High-profile Republicans such as former Senator Rick Santorum rejected McCain partially because of Lieberman.

"McCain spent the entire summer drawing a contrast between his conservativism and Clark's liberalism and Lieberman through all that through the window," said Republican strategist Scott Reed. "(But) you can't blame Lieberman for the loss. He reigned in the moderate Democrats..."”

McCain senior adviser Nicolle Wallace said the Arizona senator got a rough deal electorally from Buchanan, who "sabotaged" the Republican ticket. As a result, President Clark was able to revive a long-dead electoral coalition in the South held together by ancestral Democrats, sometimes winning states while barely holding 40% of the vote share.

"No objective analysis suggests that the Clark campaign wasn't directly helped by Buchanan. It's fair to assume Democrats did their fair share of spreading the word of Buchanan's candidacy." She said.

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/1elrxuk.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 2 && Win < 7) { // romnercare e.pages.push(`

The New Yorker | Did Mitt Romney Save His Soul?

The American Health Insurance Connector Authority reveals a liberal steak to the all-but liberal President

Published in August, 2011

In a small, cramped back-room in the halls of the ever glamorous and historical West Wing we find President Romney, sitting alongside Senate leaders Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell. Reid looks at the President and inquires into his positivity in the project to reinvent the American Healthcare system. McConnell looks more glum than usual, selecting instead to stare in idly at the carpeted floors of this chosen room away from prying eyes. Romney glances at McConnell and asks if he can throw him a bone, McConnell shakes his head, The President then understood he was in fact going at this alone.

It was perhaps less unorthodox for a Republican to see to do something like this in Massachusetts, territory of the liberal-leaning Republican and the progressive democrat but in national politics the line of left-and-right was not so blurred, nor was the cameras not as bright. His next steps were going to be covered thoroughly, so he’d have to tread carefully.

Months of cajoling, talks across the aisle and a little bit of watering down to bring some Republicans across, the American Healthcare Reform Act was signed into law by President Romney to the relative chagrin of many Republicans he pleaded with to support the law. With re-election around the corner there is muted praise from the democratic candidates and even former Vice President Crist, who since departing early this year has started what some called a hopeless campaign for the Democratic Party’s nomination just one week prior to the signing.

While the last three years have indeed been confusing politically, Romney’s rather sturdy sense of pride in the bill is evident as he recalled at the signing it was not ‘100% what everyone in this roomed wanted but it will 100% help many Americans, and I cannot think of a more noble and righteous goal in this office I have been bestowed.’

The question still lays on if the President’s bold bipartisan move will help or hurt him in the national theatre of political discourse but it is perhaps fitting to say this will without a shadow of a doubt be the most historically significant moment of his first term, perhaps with the exception of the success of Operation Neptune Spear this past spring. President Romney has absconded from Republican thinking of healthcare, will the party absconded from him next November and will he lose happily with a cleared conscience?

The Onion | Brave Immigrant Completes Spiritual Self Deportation Journey, Thanks President Romney for Giving Pointers.

April 18, 2010 || Albuquerque, New Mexico - In a dusty border town cafe just south of Arizona, 32-year-old Enrique Balbado finishes the final chapter of his memoir, "The Healing Hike Home: How I Self-Deported in 2010 and Found Myself, Barefoot and Unemployed."

Enrique is one of the thousands of immigrants who followed President Mitt Romney's self-deportation policy described as "a humane, optional exit strategy for people who have jobs and families, but also the audacity to want to stay."

"I remember when ICE agents first knocked on my door," Enrique says. "They were so gentle suggesting I deport myself, they went through all my belongings hurrying me along and my house was torn apart but they assured me this was the most humane possible way to do it."

Motivated by Romney's immigration policy and ICE agents banging down his door, Enrique sold his truck, quit his landscaping job, and began walking toward Mexico. "I didn't even know which way was south," he admits. "I used the stars, the scent of cilantro, and an outdated Taco Bell receipt with a map on the back."

Romney's presidency now hailed as a success story for the National Etiquette Restoration Act, was marked by sweeping reforms, including the Voluntary Exodus Encouragement Act, which replaced all immigration forms with a mirror and a post-it note reading, "You know what to do."

Critics like Governor Rick Perry, who conducts more forceful immigration reform in Texas, like the establishment of Texans "own Guantanamo" on a floating island built by immigrants. Romney responded to the attacks, stating, "Look, if people want to stay in America, they'll stay. But they'll go if they don't want to be hassled by federal agents disguised as Pizza Hut delivery drivers. That's the free market of residence."

Enrique rebuilt his life in Sonora as a freelance sombrero consultant and occasionally appears back in America for TED Talks, giving motivational speeches about leaving the country.

No matter the struggle, Enrique holds no ill will toward the President. "Romney taught me something. If you don't belong somewhere, you should definitely leave quietly and let the economy figure it out. That's the American way."

When confronted, President Romney nodded and said, "Good. The system works."

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/xzzafuc.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Dem == 2 && Win < 8) { // mitt L e.pages.push(`

Reuters: Why Mitt Romney lost the White House

Boston (Reuters) - Republican Mitt Romney lost Tuesday's presidential election in an upset at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The Massachusetts Governor, with a popular mandate, failed to hit the mark with key demographics once election night arrived.

As the blame game began, analysts on all sides of the aisle were launching intense scrutiny on Governor Romney and President Clark for running a "ruthlessly negative campaign."

Staunchest defenders claim the Clark campaign exploited some elements unfairly to discredit Romney. Karl Rove pitched in, arguing that the president ran against an idea more than the reality of Governor Romney's record.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally challenging political environment for Democrats, the Governor failed to make his dream a reality at the ballot box.

As a somewhat political newcomer on the national scene, Governor Mitt Romney struggled with name recognition and credibility, especially with the conservative base coming from very liberally prone Massachusetts.

But the surprise outcome isn't one without some reasoning. Many of Governor Romney's opponents during the primaries highlighted his weakness on the issues that mattered to Republicans.

In a somber-filled concession speech, Governor Romney was seemingly lost and unprepared to speak for such an outcome.

"I congratulate President Clark and pray for his success as this country faces a very difficult time," he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in Boston. "I wish I had been able to fulfill your hopes to lead the country in a different direction, but the nation chose the president so Ann and I will pray for him and this nation. God bless America."

Republican strategist John Feehery said Romney's background in business had hurt the ticket's chances, given the widespread scorn for Wall Street.

"The Clark campaign made it a key talking point to undercut Governor Romney. The "CEO" label severely hurt the support of working-class voters.

The financial crisis that erupted in September gave Romney an unbreakable lead in the polls, with Clark trailing in nearly all of the swing states.

OVERCONFIDENCE, UNPOPULAR ISSUES

Some might argue that the intense focus on immigration, which hadn't panned out to be among the top five most important issues with most demographics, led to certain demographics ditching Governor Romney.

It severely limited Governor Romney's ability to pick up Hispanic voters hurting from the recession.

The financial crisis also put Romney's background at Bain Capital at the forefront. While Clark bled in the polls, Romney's popularity with voters stagnated. Wall Street became a winning issue as Clark campaigned against their actions.

Aides of the Clark Administration seem oddly calm as if the outcome had been expected.

"It is highly doubtful that anyone will ever have an easier and more advantaged political climate than Governor Romney was given." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Romney campaign officials say that the outcome also blindsided Romney, who allegedly hadn't prepared a proper concession speech.

What about Palin? To most, Romney's pick for Vice President was as historic and costly. While some argue that Palin's selection helped the ticket shore up conservative support she wasn't at the same speed as Governor Romney.

As Romney attempted to claim the high road of competence, Palin ran hard to his right, completely ditching the center, making a fool out of herself too often.

Romney's campaign manager, Beth Myers, said the Massachusetts Governor faced unfair speculation that other candidates wouldn't have been put through. Particularly highlighting Romney's religion and career as smears the Clark campaign abused.

"The facts as they lay show that the president did not walk into this campaign hoping to participate in a fair fight. He dragged it through the mud at nearly every chance and he's got his victory but with no mandate, none at all." She said.

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

Reuters: Why Mitt Romney lost the White House

Boston (Reuters) - Republican Mitt Romney lost Tuesday's presidential election in an upset at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The Massachusetts Governor, with a popular mandate, failed to hit the mark with key demographics once election night arrived.

As the blame game began, analysts on all sides of the aisle were launching intense scrutiny on Governor Romney and President Clark for running a "ruthlessly negative campaign."

Staunchest defenders claim the Clark campaign exploited some elements unfairly to discredit Romney. Karl Rove pitched in, arguing that the president ran against an idea more than the reality of Governor Romney's record.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally challenging political environment for Democrats, the Governor failed to make his dream a reality at the ballot box.

As a somewhat political newcomer on the national scene, Governor Mitt Romney struggled with name recognition and credibility, especially with the conservative base coming from very liberally prone Massachusetts.

But the surprise outcome isn't one without some reasoning. Many of Governor Romney's opponents during the primaries highlighted his weakness on the issues that mattered to Republicans.

"I wish I had been able to fulfill your hopes to lead the country in a different direction, but the nation chose the president so Ann and I will pray for him and this nation. God bless America."

"The Clark campaign made it a key talking point to undercut Governor Romney. The "CEO" label severely hurt the support of working-class voters.

It severely limited Governor Romney's ability to pick up Hispanic voters hurting from the recession.

The financial crisis also put Romney's background at Bain Capital at the forefront. While Clark bled in the polls, Romney's popularity with voters stagnated. Wall Street became a winning issue as Clark campaigned against their actions.

"It is highly doubtful that anyone will ever have an easier and more advantaged political climate than Governor Romney was given." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Romney campaign officials say that the outcome also blindsided Romney, who allegedly hadn't prepared a proper concession speech.

As Romney attempted to ditch the businessman label, Crist served as a stark reminder of who many alleged was bought out by Romney to help save his primary campaign, delivering the key state of Florida.

"The facts as they lay show that the president did not walk into this campaign hoping to participate in a fair fight. He dragged it through the mud at nearly every chance and he's got his victory but with no mandate, none at all." She said.

The Board of Education welcomes you to the homepage for the Educational Opportunities and Advancement Act.

Highlights


Opportunity scholarships and vouchers

Each state is offered a federal grant to pay for school vouchers, which are given to successful students in failing schools who are pulled out and put into a nearby charter or private school.


State Hub for voucher applications

Application for state vouchers under Title IX, Part C, Section 9018 of the Educational Opportunities and Advancement Act. (Public Law 140-149.) Includes the Accountability Workbook.


State Hub for scholarship applications

Application for state scholarship under Title IX, Part D, Section 6098 of the Educational Opportunities and Advancement Act. (Public Law 150-159.)


Progress and performance report

State-by-state statistics tracker of the United States Department of Education. (Last updated July 8th 2010.)


Improving the quality of our teachers

Enacting the Proven Strength in Tenure Act holds teachers to greater standards as our first line of defense for greater education.

CBS News: SCATHING FAILURE -The Educational Opportunities and Advancement Act fails to pass the Senate.

Allen Hubert

Updated on: March 12, 2010/7:03 EST/ CBS NEWS

PRESIDENT BUSH: "This is a setback but the fight for greater opportunities for American youth does not stop here."

At 3 PM EST, The Senate began voting on President Bush's landmark legislation reforming the education system. Republicans unable to breach the filibuster without some Democratic crossover support were expected to pull the votes required to pass the bill.

However, failure to get the likes of Senator Nelson of Florida and other moderate Senators to surpass the filibuster had doomed the bill.

The details of the Educational Opportunities and Advancement Act rallied teachers' unions nationwide against it. The Act sought to build a school voucher system that would pull kids out of struggling schools.

Opponents levied scathing charges against the legislation as a "public school killer" that would seek to punish failing schools instead of aiding them. The legislation offers little to address the schools' problems and abandons them and students whose grades don't qualify for the vouchers program. Effective action for schools has been a public debate for some time, with Democrats demanding heavy concessions that Bush was not willing to give up.

Bush, who has a long career of fighting with teachers' unions and Democrats on education matters, went on air to criticize the "political hit job" against the bill.

At 6 PM, Bush gave a press conference alleging that "Democrats came into the Senate today with their minds made up against needed reforms for no reason beyond classic partisanship."


Why The Religious Right can't trust JebFeb 21st, 2010
Iraq Withdrawal Date Tossed Aside, Where We Go From HereSep 29th, 2009
The Recession Is Over, Why doesn't it feel like it?Feb 29th, 2010

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/7M564Pf.png'})]) } if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Dem == 3) { // Jeb L e.pages.push(`

Reuters: Why Jeb Bush lost the White House

Miami (Reuters) - - Republican Jeb Bush lost Tuesday's presidential election in an upset at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The now 3rd member of the Bush Clan to grasp the Republican Nomination for President failed to make his case to the voters.

As the blame game began, analysts on all sides of the aisle were blown away. How could this happen? With the financial crisis and Iraq in turmoil, this election seemed like a shoe victory to most.

Clark's actions left him entirely exposed to easy attacks from the right. Neoconservative icons were crawling out of the woodwork it lambast his foreign policy.

But despite all these factors, including a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally tough political environment for Democrats, the former Governor met the same fate his brother did four years prior and his father faced in 1992.

Just 4 years ago, President George W. Bush's political career ended with General Clark in what many also called a shocking upset. At the time, it was unthinkable that the man who oversaw the events of 9/11, sporting a once untouchable approval rating, could fall flat in spectacular fashion.

Now, with his brother meeting a similar fate in what should have been even easier circumstances, most are asking if the Bush name is a curse or if Wesley Clark is untouchable.

In a bewildered concession speech, the former Governor congratulated the President and spoke of the need to unite behind the President during this crisis.

"These results may not be what we all wanted, but that doesn't take away from the issues we brought attention to during this campaign," he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in Miami. "I hope President Clark takes note of this and pray that he can lead our nation into a greater future during his second term."

"Governor Bush struggled to connect with key voting demographics below college educated voters. Possibly his immigration and education stances being liberally prone like his primary opponents often highlighted."

The primary opponent Feehery is referring to was Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, who often attacked Bush for his weak stance on immigration and suggested many dedicated Republicans could be turned off by it.

OUT OF TOUCH, EASILY EXPOSED

It's hard not to blame the range of different avenues Democrats could attack Bush from, whether it was his handling of the Schiavo Case, unpopular social issues stances, or even the controversy surrounding the 2000 Florida recounts brought up.

He first championed his foreign policy, attacking President Clark's handling of the war in Iraq. While media think tanks often agreed with Bush, exit polls display Iraq as either the 3rd or 4th most important issue of the election.

The financial crisis had put economic solutions at the forefront of people's concerns. While President Clark responded calmly and firmly, Governor Bush's proposals often didn't go far enough for voters. The offer of tax cuts and reigning in government spending during a crisis and calamity had fallen flat.

Aides of the Clark Administration seem equally bewildered by the outcome.

"It is highly doubtful that anyone will ever have an easier and more advantaged political climate than Governor Bush was given." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Bush campaign officials say that the outcome was of huge disappointment and surprise to Jeb.

What about Ridge? To most, the selection of the former Pennsylvania Governor and Homeland Security Secretary did little to help sew toes with Bush's right flank, and in return, it brought about the underlying distrust of the George W. Bush Administration. As Secretary of Homeland Security, Tom Ridge oversaw an era of massive oversight and human rights violations.

While the pick didn't damage Bush's relationship with Republicans, it didn't do much to excite them.

"Bush had promised to deliver on key Republican issues during the primaries but chose to run to the center once nominated," said Republican strategist David Kochul. "Ridge isn't to blame for the loss this was of Bush's doing and him alone."

Bush campaign manager Danny Diaz said Bush ran a stellar campaign, but President Clark had nailed him on minor issues. As a result, President Clark could trade votes he lost in states struck by the recession for votes in traditionally Democratic states.

"Nothing in the exit polls tell us Governor Bush was simply unpopular by name recognition, there's more to the story and I'd like people to understand these things are complicated," he said.

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/ejSF3hx.png'})]) } if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 4) { // Rudy w e.pages.push(`

Conversation between President Rudy Giuliani and Secretary of State Condoleeza Rice

President Giuliani: Any word from Maliki agreeing to a troop redeployment?

Secretary Rice: Prime Minister al-Maliki is reluctant to agree without a firm withdrawal date; he's been giving us a hard time ever since the Clark Administration's horrendous handling of the Blackwater shooting.

President Giuliani: He's still upset about that? What kind of pansy is this guy? People die. It's war; we can't be held responsible if a few civilians get caught in the crossfire.

Secretary Rice: Well he cares, we're creating a more comprehensive plan to satiate his stomach for now.

President Giuliani: Why must we play coy with this idiot anyway? Isn't he a corrupt bastard? Let's oust him and put in someone with a backbone.

Secretary Rice: He's challenging to deal with, but there's no immediate need to demand his removal. Most of the friction was caused by Secretary Levin's constant bullying of him. Aside from that, we have all the justification we need to send troops back in.

President Giuliani: Which is?

Secretary Rice: We'll just let them kill each other, and we'll stand by and try to pick up the pieces; if they want to have a civil war, we're going to have to let them. We'll go in to pick up the pieces. When the time comes, we'll have Maliki removed to eliminate any chance he tries to get in bed with his friends in Tehran.

President Giuliani: Good, good, I don't want those bastards getting any ideas; I'm still not convinced they had no hand in 9/11; they train their children to kill Americans at two, I hear.

Secretary Rice: We'll announce the troop deployment on Tuesday, which should give Congress enough time to convene and agree.

President Giuliani: I want this to make me look good; I don't want to look like a wimp. Clark embarrassed us enough by being a wishy-washy hack.

Secretary Rice: Yes, Mr. President, the top priority is always you.

President Giuliani: Damn straight.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/mXEAC1Y.png'})]) } if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Dem == 4) { // Rudy L e.pages.push(`

Reuters: Why Rudy Giuliani lost the White House

New York City (Reuters) - Republican Rudy Giuliani lost Tuesday's presidential election in a humiliating defeat at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The celebrity Mayor, whose fame in politics could only be rivaled by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, was expected to take the polls by storm but came up short.

As the blame game began, analysts said his many weaknesses were exposed little by little. The firefighter revolting, his affairs, his ties to Bernard Kerik—it all came crashing down on him. President Clark dutifully exploited this and made the election more about Rudy's blemishes than the disaster he brewed in Iraq, not to mention the collapsing economy.

Giuliani's attempts to portray President Clark as a tax-raising socialist who let terrorists take over Iraq grew stale with moderates, and whatever gains he made with them, he lost double the evangelicals in the South.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President with a sputtering economy and a generally tough political environment for Democrats, the Mayor lost by the fundamentals in running a campaign.

After 7 years of preparing his political ascendancy to the presidency, Giuliani entered with a monumental lead and was ready to take on the issues of the working class.

But the Mayor failed to respond to the crisis with effective language, at times sounding callous and heartless and sometimes aloof to the troubles facing everyday Americans. Party strategists point to Giuliani's incoherent economic messaging, which ranged from conservative to the same "Nanny" approach he often criticized.

In a difficult-to-hear concession speech late Tuesday, the former Mayor reflected on the campaign and seemingly struggled to accept blame for his failure.

"When I think back to everything I accomplished this campaign, I'm proud of the work I've done for you," he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in New York. We fought hard for those who felt abandoned by Democrats and for the people we lost on 9/11."

Republican strategist John Feehery said Giuliani's deep ties to the Bush administration might have ended up becoming a net negative with sore wounds prevailing from Iraq.

"He was always seen next to Bush advisors like Condoleezza Rice and Donald Rumsfeld. People who were well known to the general public as war propeteers."

The financial crisis that erupted in September had seemingly solidified Giuliani's victory to most, but in early October, evidence of him paying off a mistress with city funds resurfaced, blowing through much of the Mayor's lead.

EASY CLIMATE, MASSIVE GAFFES

Giuliani deeply wounded himself after refusing to answer a question about whether or not he'd pardon his former associate Bernard Kerik if elected president. Among other gaffes, he often became his own worst enemy.

He championed himself as someone above it all while being in touch with people's needs. This backfired on many of his proposals, and Giuliani often came off as elitist and running on vanity.

The financial crisis also put Giuliani's "conservativism" under speculation. While President Clark came off as calm and strong in his response, the Mayor appeared aloof to what Americans needed. This was especially so when he got into a public feud with Senator Hillary Clinton over her broad economic plan, including freezing foreclosures nationwide.

Aides say Giuliani's response to the economic crisis muddied the debate and gave President Clark an opening.

"It is highly doubtful that anyone will ever have an easier and more advantaged political climate than Mayor Giuliani was given." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Giuliani aids say the Mayor is deeply bitter about his former campaign allies, like Senator Sam Brownback, calling on him to drop out of the race in favor of his running mate, Representative Mike Pence of Indiana.

What about Pence? To most, Giuliani's pick for Vice President helped stem the bleeding of votes to any fringe third-party candidates and contrasted well with Giuliani's more high-class profile with a lowly representative of Indiana.

Giuliani Senior Advisor Condoleezza Rice commented on the media portraying the Mayor unfairly in October.

"There's no doubt that the media portrayed the Clark and Giuliani campaigns extremely differently," Rice told reporters at the Giuliani campaign headquarters in New York. "Mayor Giuliani is not at fault for legacy media playing up irrelevant culture war issues over the war in Iraq.”

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

CNN: Bank Of America sinks, stock markets plummet with it

By Juliana Malini

11:23 PM March 13th

Newly inaugurated President Ron Paul staked opposition to future government interference in the ongoing recession well before his climactic victory against then-President Wesley Clark. Clark, who oversaw the beginning of the global recession that many economists argue started near the end of 2007, ran on a platform of rapid government response to the crisis. Paul, by contrast, spearheaded the End The Fed movement, which sought to close the Federal Reserve and end all federal government meddling in fiscal affairs.

After a spirited campaign against the establishment in the Republican primaries, Paul benefited from high independent support and even crossover support with liberal Democrats frustrated by Clark's foreign policy. Clark became the face of rage against the establishment, corporate meddling, and dishonest foreign policy focus. Soon after, Paul would be declared the race's victor once the votes were cast, solidifying an anti-establishment revolution.

Staying true to his word, President Paul quickly reined in both the Treasury and Reserve's moves to combat the recession. When word of Bank Of America's hardship hit the Oval Office, Paul valiantly declared, "Not a dime of the American taxpayer's money will go into the hands of a banker who failed his job." The Dow Jones Industrial Index plummeted 4% points just at the news of his announcement and would drop another 5% once Bank Of America collapsed. Repeating much of the sorrow impacting financial markets in the wake of Lehman's Brothers failure, stock markets nationwide plummeted.

President Paul sits jovial at the desk of American leadership, smiling with pride, believing it's all a market correction. Only a few months into his presidency, his approval rating sits at a historic low of 29% against 58% disapprove. Something he seems quite proud of as if he's to be a Jesus-like figure who will be vindicated by time.

The Republican establishment, particularly in the Senate, is still fighting in Michigan courtrooms to seat Representative Justin Amash, who beat Senator Sanders Levin by a historically close margin of less than 200 votes. Levin was appointed to finish the term of his brother Carl Levin, who was nominated Secretary of Defense by Wesley Clark after he was inaugurated. Leaders of the Republican caucus are hesitant to stand by Paul in his crusade against sensible economics, but they have yet to stand in his way. Something that will be extremely important as rumors of social security reform circle the administration.


CNN Coverage
New Jersey Attorney General Chris Christie ducks a run for governor amid Paul's pandemonium rule.
The path to killing Social Security, Do they have the votes?
Did Ron Paul just blame jewish people for the recession?

MSNBC: President Clark expected to send more troops to Iran, citing the need to "squash and kill the terrorist industrial complex from its source."

NEWS

In response to the severe terrorist attack in Israel on September 12th, President Clark led the charge in blaming Iran for funding a deep terrorist network with malicious intent. In a fashion much similar to his predecessor's handling of the Iraq War, President Clark dove head first into calling for Congress to give the go-ahead and declare war on the Islamic Republic of Iran.

Spearheaded by like-minded allies such as newly confirmed Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Senator Joe Biden, Congress gave Clark a speedy reply, granting him his wish. Iran was to feel the full, insurmountable weight of American military prowess.

Two months in American resolve remains substantial, but logistical headway into cracking Iranian strength and willpower has found little success. President Clark hails the effort as extraordinary, with victory just approaching. However, administration insider doubts lay with officials from the State Department foretelling of Iranian troop movements to block access to oil fields to begin a larger oil shortage.

Widespread protests against the war have already begun to blip up, and if an oil shortage were to further the binds of which American citizens are held, it may erupt into a large-scale public revolt. President Clark has disavowed the idea that the United States would take a step further to launch a tactical nuclear weapon, but skeptics are unwilling to give him the benefit of the doubt.

Washington stepped up the bombing campaign against Iranian military targets, including alleged nuclear facilities, despite publicly pushing for a negotiated settlement. Israel has led the charge in pointing out where the United States should strike, and President Clark, like a lap dog, ordered strikes on alleged nuclear facilities throughout Syria and Iran.

With the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff expected to provide more comprehensive requests like further troop deployments into Iran, it seems the administration is all but doubling its efforts to take down the "pillar of the terrorist industrial complex."


MSNBC Coverage
Why NATO allies are refusing to support Clark's war. (Dec 4th 2009)

Why Illinois Senator Barack Obama abstained the Iran vote. (Dec 14th 2009)

Democrats struggle to find an identity beyond Clark's marching orders. (Dec 15th 2009)

Reuters: Why Ron Paul lost the White House

Dallas (Reuters) - Republican Ron Paul lost Tuesday's presidential election at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The Libertarian-minded Congressman, whose unorthodox positions on most issues were expected to shake up the race heavily, sadly, it didn't shake how he hoped it would.

As the blame game began, analysts said his repudiation of the establishment and Senator Rick Santorum's third-party bid were among his greatest challenges to overcome. The old newsletters, past racist and antisemitic remarks, his unpopular platform—it all came crashing down on him. President Clark dutifully exploited this to avoid the challenge of his revolting left flank and set the theme of the election on Paul's unpopularity.

Paul's unstable coalition, bound by opposing President Clark's neoliberalism, ran out of steam short of its destination, and whatever gains he made with left-wing activists cost him conservative votes in the South.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally tough political environment for Democrats, the Congressman failed to grasp the fundamentals of most issues.

Eighteen years after his initial run for President with the libertarian label, he was expected to champion the anti-war coalition's banner, but a third-party sabotage candidacy drained him with key Republican demographics.

But Paul's greatest failure was of his own making. His record was electoral poison, especially when his stance on Social Security was brought to the forefront, scaring the Republican base of the 65-and-older crowd. Furthermore, he alienated the traditional Republican farm states with his outspoken criticism of farm subsidies.

In a tough-pill-to-swallow concession speech, the Representative noted the massive achievement this election was for the libertarian movement.

"We may have lost, but the ideas brought forth prove that the libertarian experiment can be accomplished," he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in Dallas. We fought hard against the establishment, and while the warmongering free-spending free-thinkers may have won this battle, the war for greater libertarian thought marches on!"

Republican strategist John Feehery said Paul's inability to compromise with the Republican establishment did him in.

"There were very few appealing aspects of Ron Paul's candidacy to the average Republican voter. He was too relaxed on social issues and let's not even get started on his foreign policy."

The financial crisis that erupted in September had seemingly boosted confidence in his candidacy, but when it came to solutions to the crisis, the appeal slowly faded away.

EASY CLIMATE, SCATHING SCRUTINY

Paul suffered heavy losses after his association with the Ron Paul Newsletter was brought to the forefront of the campaign, which highlighted past racist and antisemitic remarks.

He championed himself as the choice of both the anti-war left and right but found that these two groups were incompatible on several issues like abortion and economics.

The financial crisis initially vindicated Paul's platform as he championed ideas like ending the Federal Reserve. While President Clark focused on bailing financial institutions, Paul advocated smashing the established financial norms. The movement he sparked drew crowds, but its limited reach grew apparent when most desperately pleaded for a firm government response.

Aides say Paul's response to the crisis, while helping keep a dedicated following, did little to combat the stigma of Paul as a radical.

"It is highly doubtful that any Republican will collapse in the fasion that the Paul campaign has." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Paul aides say the Congressman is bitter and frustrated over the surprisingly popular conservative party candidacy of Rick Santorum.

What about Johnson? To most, Paul's selection of former New Mexico Governor Gary Johnson only doubled down on his outsider appeal and further drove a divide between Paul and the Republican establishment.

Paul's Press Secretary Jesse Benton commented that the Republican establishment lost them this campaign.

"There's no doubt that the Republican establishments refusal to get behind our campaign lost us this election," Benton told reporters at the Giuliani campaign headquarters in New York. "Congressman Paul ran a fantastic campaign that will be hailed for generations as a trendsetter, we had the best funding of any Republican campaign and lost because other Republicans sabotaged our efforts."

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

Reuters: Why Mike Huckabee lost the White House

Hope (Reuters) - —Republican Mike Huckabee lost Tuesday's presidential election in an upset defeat at the behest of President Wesley K. Clark. The rising star Governor of Arkansas, who took the mantle of the Republican nomination and fended off fierce establishment competitors, was expected to take the incumbent President to task but came up short.

As the blame game began, Republican analysts seemed to be scratching their heads while most Democrats stood vindicated in their predictions. A leaked memo from a Democratic staffer revealed that most Democrats hoped Republicans would nominate Huckabee, remarking that he'd be "their McGovern."

Huckabee's attempts to chastise Clark for the situation in Iraq fell flat when he couldn't correctly articulate a winning solution. Other Republican candidates for the nomination had often attacked the former Governor for his foreign policy know-how and lack thereof. It appears they had a point.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally tough political environment for Democrats, the former Governor lost sight of the fundamentals.

The blindsided establishment never saw Huckabee coming, and Republicans believed that the same trend would launch Huckabee into the White House.

However, the Governor failed to respond to the crisis with reasonable solutions, and when he did have a good point, it was overshadowed by his more extreme positions. Party strategists point to Huckabee's advocation for another constitutional convention as a turn-off to moderates.

In a humbling concession speech late Tuesday, the former Governor reflected on the campaign and held a moment for prayer congratulating President Clark.

"This was truly a spectacular campaign and i'm glad we could share it together," he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in Hope. "I pray for the safety of our troops and hope that President Clark will keep them safe."

Republican strategist John Feehery said Huckabee's repeated alienation of his Republican opponents like Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney would lead to a fractured party.

"He had alienated the Mormons, the catholics, the Jewish. He made slights against key demographics he needed right win."

President Clark held an early lead in the polls, which soon collapsed amid the failure of Lehman Brothers. The economic calamity had cemented the idea that it was Huckabee's election to lose now.

EASY CLIMATE, GAFFES AND STUPIDITY

Among the greatest gaffes the former Governor made on the campaign trail, his insensitive references to the Holocaust when making different points had cut down on the lead gained in September.

He championed himself as inclusive to all religions, but his folksy' preaching rhetoric became a turn-off to most outside the protestant faith.

The financial crisis also highlighted Huckabee's spending habits. While most Republicans demanded cutting down on spending, Huckabee advocated for massive infrastructure projects.

Aides say Huckabee's response to the economic crisis created a rift between himself and common-sense conservatives, allowing an opening for President Clark to thread the needle.

"Truthfully we had expected this outcome, our internal polling consistently showed Huckabee trailing as opposed to some of his primary opponents." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Huckabee campaign officials say the Governor was extremely upset that so-called "foreign policy experts" with the Republican Party were reluctant to back him.

What about Thompson? To most, Huckabee's choice for Vice President united the party establishment worried about his lack of foreign policy expertise. While not providing strategic regional balance, Thompson was a common sense conservative Huckabee needed.

Huckabee's campaign manager, Ed Rollins, commented that the media was portraying the former Governor unfairly.

"The world is collapsing under Clark's oversight but the media instead chose to criticize Huckabee's as untested? "Rollins told reporters at the Huckabee campaign headquarters in Hope, Arkansas. "The biased media is to blame for Governor Huckabee's defeat."

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

MEMORANDUM

DATE: APRIL 9TH, 2009

TO: PUBLIC

FROM: HERITAGE OVERSIGHT PROJECT

SUBJECT: KEY PROPOSALS SUBMITTED TO THE HUCKABEE ADMINISTRATION

REGARDING CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION

The Heritage Foundation's Oversight Project has just submitted a list of high-value proposals for President Mike Huckabee to consider when calling a constitutional convention. In accordance with the submittal, the Oversight Project has also requested a formal meeting with the President and a seat at the table if such a convention were to be called. If the President were to act by our wishes, we would aid him in his effort to rewrite the wrongs of the Founding Fathers.

Key proposals for such a convention include a national ban on gay marriage, a national abortion ban, a balanced budget amendment, a freedom of religious speech amendment, a national ban on gun control, a Ten Commandments amendment, a flat tax amendment, an amendment deregulating the energy industry, and a closed borders amendment.

President Huckabee has yet to respond to our goals, but his political alignment gives us confidence that a major step forward is at hand. In the coming days, Heritage Foundation agents will coalesce in Washington to discuss the path forward to getting our proposals through Congress in the case President Huckabee backs down. Regardless, the path toward enacting our agenda has never been clearer with the sturdy Republican Congress.
