`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/ynZLjx2.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Dem == 7) { // Brownback L e.pages.push(`

Reuters: Why Sam Brownback lost the White House

Kansas City (Reuters) - —Republican Sam Brownback lost Tuesday's presidential election at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The establishment Senator turned Tea Party preacher sought the full erratic support of the Republican base to bring a more traditionalist view to the American Government.

As the blame game began, analysts pointed to one aspect of his campaign: hate. Sam Brownback campaigned on the rage of evangelical Christians, hoping to turn out a large and capable coalition, but his many weaknesses disturbed the moderates within the party. President Clark, by contrast, campaigned to stop hate of all forms, garnering his dedicated following as a result.

While Brownback's coalition was loyal and dedicated, he lacked support among key groups, especially those most concerned with foreign policy.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally tough political environment for Democrats, the Senator failed to convince voters on fundamental issues.

Brownback's entry into politics was profoundly unrecognizable compared to the way he conducted this campaign. Once an advocate for bipartisanship, Brownback seemingly dropped all compromise within his heart after Clark pushed the Freedom To Marry Act.

The failure to compromise became Brownback's downfall as his full embrace of populist themes quickly eroded through the patience of establishment Republicans. Radical tax positions, even for a Republican, combined with his extreme views on abortion and dovish foreign policy, limited the range of his coalition.

In his concession speech, which was followed by a prayer, the Senator noted the massive, glorious movement that enveloped his campaign.

"I know this loss hangs heavy in our hearts but believe me when I say, we've accomplished more for our Christian faith during this campaign than anyone could have ever imagined." he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in Kansas City. "I still dream of a day where our deeply religious population aren't held captive by activist governments and that dream is still within reach, we must keep fighting for our children, for our grandchildren and for Christ!"

Republican strategist John Feehery said Brownback's deeply religious campaign reawakened a populist element within the Republican Party.

"The crowds he generated weren't just excited, they were frothing for change and praying in unison with him."

The financial crisis only encouraged the Senator to redouble his efforts on populist talking points like his great tax experiment and massive deregulations.

EASY CLIMATE, TOO RADICAL

Brownback was committed to the idea that the separation between church and state had to be abolished, so much so that he mentioned his Christian faith in every facet of the campaign, from foreign policy to economics.

He championed himself as a Christian first and a senator second, which quickly gave his campaign a unique and colorful image.

The financial crisis had blown through President Clark's lead, and most believed Brownback could make a comeback in the same spirit as Bill Clinton in 1992. However, through laser-focused determination and inspiring leadership, President Clark was able to repel Brownback's gains and lead the nation through the crisis convincingly.

Aides said Brownback's plan for the government cuts, while appealing to a significant portion of his base, worried fiscal hawks, who were unsure how the United States could pay for such extreme tax cuts.

"It is a great sigh of relief that Senator Brownback's hateful campaign was rejected." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Brownback aides say the Senator is jubilant, seemingly believing his strategy was vindicated for coming as close as it did.

What about Bachmann? To most, Brownback's choice for running mate was initially brave and inspirational but soon became an utter nightmare when her radical tendencies came to the forefront, especially her strange beliefs on bullying and even more dangerous ideas of gutting social security.

Brownback's campaign manager, Rob Wasinger, defended the campaign's radical stances, claiming they were not out of step with standard Republican ideology.

"The Republican Party was behind this campaign 100% and we need to acknowledge how close we came to victory," Wasinger told reporters at the Brownback campaign headquarters in Kansas City. "Senator Brownback ran a historic campaign and we would be fools to ditch the ideas he brought forth in four years."

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/8yLBJIp.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 7 && Win < 5 && War == 0) { // FMA e.pages.push(`

President celebrates passage of the Federal Marriage Amendment

Remarks by the President

The Briefing Room

10:43 A.M. EST

THE PRESIDENT:Good Morning, 2 years ago I promised you that I would protect marriage and firmly end the efforts of activist judges and state legislatures of trying to destroy the sanctity of our Christian faith.

I'm happy to announce that the Federal Marriage Amendment has passed the House by 237-198 and the Senate by 61-37. This is a monumental victory not only for protecting our faith but eliminating this pointless partisan issue.

The amendment declares that: (1) marriage in the United States shall consist only of the union of a man and a woman; and (2) neither the U.S. Constitution nor the constitution of any state shall be construed to require that marriage or the legal incidents of marriage be conferred upon any other union.

After more than two centuries of basic common decency being followed my hand was forced after rogue justices declared what a millennia of human experience had never dreamed of allowing. While I wish this issue could have solely been relegated to the states I understand that the people's voice must come before the voices of these activist judges.

I believe our nation can now truly pursue greater progress while still following the word of God. Human experience has proven that the commitment of a husband and wife to love and to serve one another promotes the welfare of children and the stability of society. The good nature of our society is reliant on these core beliefs. We all should and must follow the Bible, long has the government ignored its power. The separation of church and state was a norm not a rule and its time we realize that these norms cannot be followed if the government seeks to meddle in issues that the Bible is concerned with.

This is a great victory for all under God and I hope the American public comes to appreciate it.

Thank you very much.

END 10:47 A.M. EST

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/iKKfILD.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 7 && War == 0) { // FMA e.pages.push(`

CNN: Is Grassley going to lose?

By Jessica Frowigs

With the 2010 midterm elections looming over Brownback's mandate like a storm, local Iowan petitioners and protesters are demanding Senator Grassley to roll back the "Great American Tax Experiment," which has made its impact on both the minds and wallets of thousands of Iowans statewide. The bill, which made landfall in late 2009 amid an already limping economy wounded from the great recession, has all but helped the Middle and lower classes.

The Great American Tax Experiment was passed through Congress with the promise of encouraging job growth with radical tax cuts on the super wealthy. Instead, the United States underwent a historic downgrade of its credit rating after budget shortfalls and negotiations over the debt ceiling stalled and left the world holding its breath. Since then, the Democratic Party has seized the narrative, nationalizing local races from top to bottom, with the culmination of Republican worries manifesting under the heel of Senator Chuck Grassley's reelection bid.

After touring through the state hearing out the woes of everyday Iowans, former Governor Tom Vilsack threw his hat into the ring to challenge Grassley, believing the entrenched Senator had lost his touch with Iowa folk. Collecting a coalition of aching teamster representatives, working families unable to afford their groceries, and farmers denied access to Healthcare after Medicaid and Medicare cuts sliced through the national budget, Vilsack currently polls just behind Grassley, stepping on his heels.

The movement to repudiate the Brownback agenda isn't just a Democratic play for power; moderate Republicans in swing districts have begun to draw up their amendment to the bill, hoping to pull back the political tiger clawing at their reelection efforts. Income taxes would go up, and millions of homeowners nationwide would pay taxes again to avoid any more budget shortfalls shortly, but for Democrats, it isn't a compromise; they want to tear Brownback apart. Facing scorn from all sectors of the political arena for the cuts made to the welfare state, leaving those in need helpless.

Grassley finds himself not just in a fight to defend himself but also in a battle to protect the incumbent president whom he has stood by thus far. A reelection bid hoping that nice words and smiles can make Iowa's Middle and lower class forget that it was the Republican Party that took their access to healthcare away, it was President Brownback who gutted the federal government's ability to upkeep hospitals and roads. It was Senator Chuck Grassley who voted to annihilate the national budget in favor of making the rich richer while allowing those without a comfortable yacht to sleep in to find themselves pulled down by an economic riptide.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/mZW0xsc.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Dem == 8) { // Brownback L e.pages.push(`

Reuters: Why Dick Cheney lost the White House

Houston (Reuters) - Republican Dick Cheney lost Tuesday's presidential election burdened by chaos at the hands of President Wesley Clark. The former Vice President, who had a habit of making a villain out of those who opposed them, fell short of the widely expected routing of Wesley Clark.

As the blame game began, analysts came to a multitude of conclusions. The controversial convention nomination, Huckabee supporters staying home, an uncharismatic campaign, and his unpopularity were all floated possibilities. President Clark dutifully exploited this and made the election a referendum on the decisions made by the "Cheney White House" 4 years prior.

Cheney's attempts to portray Clark as a failure in foreign affairs failed to turn heads meaningfully. He often found himself the lone voice shouting to the heavens.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally tough political environment for Democrats, the Vice President collapsed under the weight of his own failings.

If you had asked anyone at George W. Bush's 2004 election night rally if Republicans would nominate his unpopular number 2, most would have laughed in your face.

What Cheney failed to provide was a popular agenda to justify why he had to rip the nomination from Huckabee's hands essentially. Running on a platform of vindication would only carry him so far and proved not to get the voters out into booths for him.

In a cold concession speech, the Vice President reflected on his campaign accepting fault, but like many who voted against him, the crowd felt his apology was disingenuous.

"Clearly, the American people have made their decision, and the numbers aren't in our favor," he told his supporters at a somber post-election rally in Houston. I'm sorry that they failed to understand the gravity of what is at stake, and I pray that the president understands the mandate given to him."

Republican strategist John Feehery said that when presented with the actions of the Bush administration, the American people rebuked them.

"The general public is not willing to go back to what they already voted against once. Hoping for Bush to be vindicated was a losing strategy for Republicans."

The financial crisis that erupted in September had given Republicans confidence that even if Cheney had not earned the nomination fairly, he would be elected via Clark's sheer incompetence.

EASY CLIMATE, WRONG CANDIDATE

Polls after the convention projected that if Governor Mike Huckabee had won the nomination, he'd have led Clark by a comfortable margin. Other polls for candidates such as Senator John McCain and Governor Mitt Romney concluded a similar outcome.

Governor Huckabee, who went into the Republican National Convention, was widely expected to be the party's nominee until party insiders worked to find a better consensus candidate. After four ballots, Cheney became their pick.

The financial crisis also put Cheney's government experience under speculation. While President Clark came off as calm and firm in his response, the Vice President came off as cold and uncaring for families hurting from the crisis.

Clark's aides claim that Cheney was doomed to lose from the beginning and that the circumstances he squandered were enormous.

"It is highly doubtful that anyone will ever have an easier and more advantaged political climate than Dick Cheney was given." - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Cheney aides claim that the Huckabee camp is to blame for not helping the Republican ticket get across the finish line.

What about Snowe? To most, Cheney's pick for Vice President failed to bring out enough independents to make her selection worthwhile and alienated Huckabee supporters who hoped to be thrown a bone.

Cheney Senior Advisor John Bolten concluded that Republican Party extremists dropped the ball.

"The Republican Party needs to back away from extremist elements within the party and put forward responsible and feasible platforms," Bolten told reporters at the Cheney campaign headquarters in Houston. "The Vice President ran a campaign for all Americans, those Republicans who stayed home should be ashamed of themselves."

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

The Daily Show with Jon Stewart

[Intro Music Plays]

Jon Stewart (sitting at a desk):

"Welcome to The Daily Show; I'm Jon Stewart. Thank you so much, folks! My guest tonight, former mayor, expert in uttering the words nine-eleven, and possible 2010 New York gubernatorial nominee Rudy oh wait, he's just teasing a run to promote his next book.”

[Graphic: "OPERATION: STOP TIME-OUT" with a poorly made drawing of Dick Cheney shooting a glove like a basketball and missing the hoop.]

Jon:

"Big news from Washington where President Dick Cheney, America's favorite appetizer before the apocalypse, received a shocking defeat in the House of Representatives.

[Cut to C-SPAN clip: Speaker of the House banging gavel]

"The motion to authorize war against the Islamic Republic of Iran is rejected, 225 to 210."

Jon (mock shocked):

"What? Always conniving and plotting congressional freaks have voted against going to war? Are we still in America? Or did the functioning democracy pills finally kick in?"

[Graphic: "Earth shattered"]

Jon:

"President Cheney pushed this war on credible drone imagery and gut instinct, a lot of gut, and was reportedly furious to hear that Congress found a heart.”

[Video: Cheney's reaction to the news]

Cheney:

"Congress is ignorant to the facts or the Democrats are now in bed with Iran. This should not have happened."

[Cut back to Jon]

Jon:

"Yes, how dare Congress exercise its Constitutional power to declare war or not. It's almost like they read the Constitution!”

[Graphic: "Cheney's War board" — A dartboard with Iraq and Afghanistan hit, but Iran just missed slightly.]

Jon:

"Let's review, Iraq was a war for peace, Afghanistan a hunt for Bin Laden and Iran is? What? The third Burger King crown the president wears while chewing his food?"

Jon (mock Cheney voice):

"Iran is funding terrorism, Iran is destabilizing Iraq, Iran gave me a wedgie!

[Cut to a clip of Rep. Barbara Lee (D-CA) speaking on the House floor:]

"No war can be authorized before diplomacy is tried. War is a final solution not the warning shot."

Jon:

"Man we're discussing really radical concepts this week aren't we. This just in you need to wipe after you take a shit! The Democrats are really sticklers now aren't they!"

[Graphic: "Talk First, Bomb Never?"]

Jon:

"Of course Cheney has already stormed out of Congress with a plan to neuter congress so he can do what he wants anyway."

Jon (as Cheney):

"I've led the government from the shadows since the turn of the centuries. I didn't do all this just to get vetoed by elected officials! What the hell are checks and balances?

Jon:

"So maybe America is growing as a nation. A country where Congress doesn't roll over and give a paw when and where the president asks.”

[Final Graphic: "Cheney Denied: The Axis of just saying no."]

Jon:

"We'll be right back."

Reuters: Why Olympia Snowe lost the White House

Casper (Reuters) - Republican Olympia Snow lost Tuesday's presidential election in a tumultuous upset to President Wesley Clark—the bipartisan Senator who assumed the head of the ticket following former Vice President Cheney's exit.

As the blame game began, analysts weren't shocked by the outcome despite many Republicans believing Snowe could make a comeback following Cheney's horrific debate performance.

Cheney dropped out of the race due to being hospitalized after suffering a heart attack at the Presidential Debate. The widely televised moment tanked Republican polling across the board.

Despite a deeply unpopular Democratic President, a sputtering economy, and a generally challenging political environment for Democrats, the national embarrassment of replacing Cheney so late in the race undid whatever gains the ticket made.

It appeared that the entire Republican Party had united behind Senator Snowe, partly due to sympathies for the Vice President, but the base didn't show up for her on election day.

But the surprise outcome isn't one without some reasoning. Senator Snowe had made avoidable mistakes, such as campaigning with moderate Democrats like Joe Lieberman, who was reviled by social conservatives.

In a disappointing concession speech, Senator Snowe reflected on the campaign and spoke of her eagerness to continue her career of bipartisanship.

"Thank you for everything. This campaign may have come up short, but that doesn't take away from the issues we fought for," she told her supporters at a somber post election rally at Cheney's former campaign headquarters in Dallas, Texas. "We can't forget to always work with the other side of the aisle to find a solution."

Republican strategist John Feehery said Cheney cratered Republicans through his exit.

"The undeniable truth is Vice President Cheney set Senator Snowe up for failure. The dubious way he got the nomination had already burnt bridges with the right but his health concerns raise questions as to why he even ran in the first place."

The financial crisis that erupted in September provided the greatest lead Republicans could ever hope for, but Republicans failed to make a case while dealing with so many party divisions.

OPPORTUNITY, BAD MESSAGING

The Republican message had transformed from concerns over the situation in Iraq and national security to bipartisanship at a time of crisis. The message didn't do much for voters looking for a solution beyond compromise and reaching across the aisle.

Snowe championed her bipartisan voting record to contrast herself from President Clark's "radical partisan behavior." On the other hand, President Clark adopted a dedicated base who crawled over glass to vote for him.

The financial crisis also scrutinized Senator Snowe's solutions. President Clark was leading the charge of the government's response to the calamity, and Snowe was on record for voting for it. While proclaiming a deficit hawk, the vote for Clark's proposals went against her message.

Aides of the Clark Administration seem unsurprised by the outcome.

"It was highly doubtful that Snowe could manage to pull her campaign out of the shadow of Mr. Cheney's exit" - Nancy Parrish, White House Chief of Staff.

Top Snowe campaign officials say that the outcome followed equally poor internal polling.

What about Ashcroft? To most, Snowe's pick for Vice President hurt the ticket by connecting itself to some of the most unpopular aspects of the prior Bush Administration.

Ashcroft was selected amid an empty field of candidates willing to risk their careers on Snowe's last-minute salvage operation of what was left of Cheney's coattails.

"We had already spent all our energy on recovering and distancing ourselves from Cheney but Ashcroft brought back all these feelings for the Bush Administration," said Republican strategist Karl Rove. "It was unfair, the entire situation was unfair."

Roveater commented on the Clark campaign's conduct being "wholly inappropriate." Lambasting the president for delegitimizing the political process with his hyper-partisan and mean campaign against Cheney.

"The President should be held responsible for the state Vice President Cheney is in right now. The press and the Democrats colluded against us." He said.

Editing by Alan Elsner

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

`) e.executable.push([1, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/XLFJEB0.png'})]) } // midterm if ( quickstats[0] <= 140 && Agenda > 2) { // e.pages.push(`

Against the Current: A Vice President’s Reckoning with the Clark PresidencyBy Mary Landrieu

Description:

In this searing, behind the scenes political memoir, former Vice President Mary Landrieu offers a candid, unflinching account of her turbulent years in the White House under President Wesley Clark (2005–2009). A presidency marked by bold ambitions, political missteps, and ultimately, electoral defeat.

As the first female Vice President from the Deep South, Landrieu entered the West Wing hoping to bridge the growing divide between progressive ideals and pragmatic governance. Instead, she found herself increasingly at odds with a president whose bold, but politically tone deaf agenda left middle America behind. From divisive social policy experiments to aggressive environmental shifts that alienated energy dependent states, Landrieu chronicles her growing disillusionment with an administration that, in her view, governed too far outside the mainstream.

With firsthand insights, private Oval Office conversations, and previously unreleased correspondence, Against the Current unpacks::

The internal clashes over Clark’s rapid push for military and social reforms.

The political cost of ignoring moderate and working class voters.

How Katrina, healthcare reform, and rural energy policy became fault lines in the administration.

The mounting tensions between Landrieu and Clark as the 2008 election approached.

Why their campaign collapsed under the weight of idealism unmoored from political reality.

A rare and honest reflection from inside the highest levels of American government, this book is both a cautionary tale and a call to action for leaders who hope to build durable coalitions in a divided nation. Whether you’re a political junkie, a historian, or a disenchanted centrist, Against the Current is a must read look at what happens when vision collides with governance and when a Vice President says, “Enough.”

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/qU0m09t.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 230 && Agenda > 2) { // e.pages.push(`

CNN INTERVIEW TRANSCRIPT

Air Date: August 10, 2009

Host: Anderson Cooper

Guest: Rahm Emanuel, Former Congressman and Democratic Strategist

Anderson Cooper:

Former Congressman Rahm Emanuel, one of the Democratic Party's sharpest political strategists, will join us tonight. It's good to have you here, Rahm.

Rahm Emanuel:

Thanks, Anderson. Good to be with you.

Anderson Cooper:

So, the dust has settled, and I think we have had enough time to analyze what went wrong last year, but I'd love to know where you think the Democrats failed. Why did Clark lose?

Rahm Emanuel:

Look, Anderson, elections are about contrast and confidence. Voters faced two major conflicts, one at home and the other abroad. Clark ran an administration filled with ambition, passing bold ideas without caring about the political ramifications of such legislation. Labels mean a lot in this business, and the President getting stuck with the word "radical" on his forehead hurt the team. That scared a lot of voters in the middle.

Anderson Cooper:

Clark often justified his momentum based strategy by arguing that the base would be hardened and remain committed to the Democrats as long as things were getting done. Why do you think that failed?

Rahm Emanuel:

It's pretty simple. People like consistency; they want to feel secure. Clark often attacked the system that elected him and thus was rejected because people felt scared. He had a legislative freight train built, and instead of saying "all aboard," he tied parts of the Democratic coalition on the railroad and ran right over them. It came off as ideological overreach rather than pragmatic leadership.

Anderson Cooper:

Wasn't Clark trying to seize a moment of transformation after the Bush years?

Rahm Emanuel:

Of course, he was, and that's a noble mission, but transforming the system doesn't mean you need to burn it to the ground. The President needs to work through the system, build trust, and build alliances. Clark was a general; he led troops and the country, but politics required more chess and less blitzkrieg.

Anderson Cooper:

Some argue that the base wanted that sweeping change. Clark was answering a demand from the left.

Rahm Emanuel:

That's exactly right and exactly what went wrong. Yes, the base was fired up, and we watched the DNC shout "Go Wes Go" altogether, but a healthy coalition is more than your core supporters. You need to reach out to independents, moderates, and even across the aisle. You have to govern in prose, not poetry. Clark offered a manifesto, not a strategy.

Anderson Cooper:

So, is this a rejection of progressive ideas?

Rahm Emanuel:

Not entirely. It's a rejection of how they were sold. You want to reform the financial system? Sure, but you need to go at it carefully. You can't take an axe to a tree that reigns over your home. Republicans were given an easy message to run with: "Big government. Big taxes. Big risk."

Anderson Cooper:

Final question: What lesson should Democrats take into 2012?

Rahm Emanuel:

Discipline, sequencing, humility. The country doesn't want revolution; it wants stability. The Clinton years may seem like a long time ago, but they were a successful eight years that merely had one hiccup in 2000. That won't happen again. Democrats need to provide continuity to move back to where the voters are, not where Clark wished they were.

Anderson Cooper:

Always candid; thank you for your time.

Rahm Emanuel:

Thank you, Anderson.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/uBmUDGM.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 230 && Agenda < 3) { // e.pages.push(`

CNN INTERVIEW TRANSCRIPT

Air Date: August 12, 2009

Host: Anderson Cooper

Guest: Rahm Emanuel, Former Congressman and Senior Advisor to the Clark Campaign

Anderson Cooper:

Rahm Emanuel, senior strategist and close advisor to General Wesley Clark's 2008 presidential campaign, joins us now. Rahm, thanks for being here.

Rahm Emanuel:

Thanks, Anderson. It's always a pleasure.

Anderson Cooper:

Let's jump straight to it. President Clark ran an overly cautious and risk averse campaign, hugging establishment norms and presenting himself as Bush without the baggage. Losing what many felt was a turnout election. What did you feel on the ground?

Rahm Emanuel:

Let's be clear: This was a wartime election. Financial institutions and the stock markets had begun to wither and decay before either party held its convention. We made the smart calculation that the American people were looking for calm, collected, and confident leadership able to steady the ship.

Anderson Cooper:

But it didn't land. Voters didn't buy it. Republicans, Democrats, and independents entered the voting booths, hoping for change.

Rahm Emanuel:

There's a difference between misreading the moment and respecting it. Republicans can promise the moon; Democrats explain how we will govern responsibly. It wasn't sexy, but it was serious, we offered maturity, respect for the institutions, and the character of our people that was on the line. It might have cost us flashy aesthetics, but it was not bad judgment.

Anderson Cooper:

You say that, but internal memos, including one you allegedly authored, limited Clark's range. Instead of allowing the President to expand on bolder ideas that polled well even within swing states, you handed him a script with limited talking points.

Rahm Emanuel:

Governing isn't about pie in the sky promises; it's about building a machine able to win elections long term and creating a coalition that can reach independents and even those across the aisle.

Anderson Cooper:

But you didn't win. You lost. Republicans won independents comfortably while youth and minority turnout collapsed for Democrats.

Rahm Emanuel:

[Pauses] Anderson, It's easy to play visionary when you aren't in the room. The rising tides of challenges we faced would make anyone consider a laundry list of proposals, believe me. There was nothing we could do to change the fundamentals of the circumstances.

Anderson Cooper:

With respect, Rahm, you were in the room. You helped shape a message that effectively failed to impress voters. How much farther can you compromise?

Rahm Emanuel:

Alright, no. You are looking for a scapegoat, and I'm not your guy. We played the best cards we could on hand, and I'm proud of the campaign we ran. We did what we thought was right.

Anderson Cooper:

Even if that means you lost?

Rahm Emanuel:

Sometimes, leadership is learning to lose the right way.

Anderson Cooper:

Or just losing.

Rahm Emanuel:

[Removes mic] We're done here.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/npu9nKK.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Agenda > 2) { // e.pages.push(`

Wesley Clark for Mayor of Chicago 2011

A New Mission for Chicago: Leadership. Integrity. Results.

Meet Wesley Clark

Born in Chicago in 1944, Wesley Clark is a decorated four-star general, former NATO Supreme Allied Commander, and a former President. After retiring from the military, Wesley Clark relinquished his civilian life for a higher calling: the presidency. After valiantly leading the country, the former president has returned to his hometown, hoping to deliver the same kind of results he achieved for Americans nationwide.

Why I'm Running

Chicago stands at a crossroads. After two decades of entrenched politics and offering a slate of candidates out of touch with the people's needs, I stood up for the people, running a Draft Clark movement once more. The people of Chicago need a bold and swift action plan to propel the city into high gear. Other candidates in the race, such as Rahm Emanuel, come with a substantial war chest backed by a political elite that is out of touch with hard-working Chicagoans. I plan to lead a more accountable and ambitious city government to help you, Chicago.

The Clark Plan for Chicago

1. Safer Streets, Stronger Communities

Implement higher standards for police and drafting many more to keep our children safe.

Initiate advanced youth mentorship and after-school programs to prevent crimes before they happen.

Reinvigorate emergency response systems to ensure that when help is needed, it arrives as quickly as possible.

2. Economic Renewal for Every Ward

Launch a "Made in Chicago" initiative to encourage purchasing from local, homegrown businesses.

Enhance job creation infrastructure in both the private and public sectors, particularly in the fields of energy, cybersecurity, and healthcare.

Lower taxes on smaller businesses to ensure growth from the bottom up.

3. Education That Works

Guaranteed universal Pre-K for all Illinois families.

Funding increases for public schooling, as well as improvements to STEM and Art departments.

Combat rising tuition costs for colleges and the creation of a public fund for ROTC-based colleges to compete with private institutions.

Join the Movement

This campaign is about unleashing the potential of everyone in Chicago and bringing a progressive agenda unshackled from upper-class elitists. Join our team, share your ideas, and help shape the future of our city.

[Volunteer]

[Donate]

[Events]

[Contact Us]

Endorsements

"Nobody in this race has the experience and capabilities of President Clark and I feel confident endorsing his bold and far reaching agenda."

-South Side Illinois Democratic Party

"His commitment to public service and to the people of Chicago is unmistakable."

-Veterans' Association of Illinois

Stay Connected

Follow us on social media for the latest updates and events :

Facebook:@DraftClarkForChicago

Twitter: @DraftClark4Chi

Instagram: @DraftClarkForChicago

Paid for by Draft Clark for Chicago 2011

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/RH1UCCl.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Agenda < 3) { // e.pages.push(`

Draft Clark 2012

Draft Clark 2012? Voters on the ground pass, but primary polling remains leading other major candidates.

As polling for the 2012 election mulls over in the minds of many voters in key states like Iowa and New Hampshire, the Democratic Party is grappling with the reality that if the former president were to run again, he'd likely win both contests. Iowa and New Hampshire were the key states that propelled Clark from a tight race with then-Senator John Kerry to stardom, painting the broader national race with his name. While other candidates build their national profile with rigorous whistle-stop tours through the states, the faint chanting of "Go Wes Go" remains in the background.

In 2008, when most polls indicated that Clark was to be swept up in a red tsunami amid the global recession, the president had rallied his party and presented a solid front to his record and ability to combat the crisis. In a polling upset, Clark outperformed expectations widely by 6-8 points nationally. While Republicans won the day, nonetheless, Democrats find it hard not to reward and commend the effort that effectively saved many of their careers, taking shelter under his name on the ballot.

When asked if he was thinking of running again, the former president claimed, "I don't like to make commitments to conflicts unless I know I'm needed." He declined to comment on the possibility of a run any further, and many suspect he's planning to sit this one out. The president stayed busy growing his business affairs, writing books, and running his cybersecurity tech firm, Clark & Co Cyberspace Protections.

Known candidates, such as Hillary Clinton, seemingly remain deathly afraid of the possibility of a Wesley Clark 2012 campaign. Former President Bill Clinton allegedly confronted Clark, asking him to stay out of the way. The often stubborn general, who had turned president, reportedly seemed annoyed while leaving his home in Chicago, Illinois.

If Clark were to jump into the race, he'd become the first former president to throw his hat into the ring of a presidential election since Herbert Hoover. Republicans often draw a connection between him and Hoover to drive home the point that the recession was a "Democrats fault." The messaging, however, proved unimpressive after the 2010 midterms, which saw Republicans undergo a severe lashing on every level of government. So, although Clark ranks 4th or 5th in national polling among Democratic candidates against the Republicans, he remains in the top 3 in the first 5 Democratic contests. The door is open to a Wesley Clark comeback to sweep the nation. It depends on whether the people of Iowa and New Hampshire are so forgiving.

AP: President Wesley K. Clark Defies Supreme Court Ruling on Foreclosure Moratorium Extension

April 10, 2008 — Washington, D.C.

Executive-judicial tensions that had built up over the past weeks have now boiled over following the President's rebuke of the recent Supreme Court ruling on his extension of the nationwide foreclosure moratorium. The Court's finding that his executive order was, in fact, unconstitutional sparked Wesley Clark's escalation into a constitutional crisis that neither congressional Democrats nor Republicans seemed interested in interfering with.

President Clark, reelected in November 2008 on the strength of his administration's response to the recession, had initially been issued the moratorium weeks before the election at the height of the housing crisis. When presenting his wide-ranging bailout initiative, he regarded the bill as "the failsafe to save America." While the original moratorium, enacted with congressional support, was set to expire in November 2009, Clark's recent unilateral extension via executive order was struck down in a 5-4 ruling by the Supreme Court, citing separation of powers and a lack of legislative authority.

Almost as if the President was quoting Andrew Jackson himself, Clark responded to the ruling at a Monday press briefing, "The Court has made its opinion known, and so have I. I'd like to see them enforce it. I answer to America, not a political bench held by echoes of a bygone era."

The White House continues to argue that the President holds unilateral authority, citing that the American economy is beginning to affect foreign policy. White House Chief of Staff commented, saying, "We are choosing stability over procedure, and for the President to effectively manage the country's foreign policy, we need a stable home front.

Legal scholars are deeply divided on the events, arguing that the President's actions risk setting a precedent that could destroy judicial authority for years to come. Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, a former Harvard president, is noticeably quiet on the issue, simply carrying out the President's directives.

Yet the President's approval ratings continue to surge, particularly among working-class and minority groups still recovering from the financial crash. Recent Gallup polls show that the approval of the moratorium has risen to 68%, while approval of Clark's recent actions lags not far behind at 59%.

Republican congressional leaders remain paralyzed following a failure to launch an impeachment inquiry over the President's actions. House Republican Leader Eric Cantor has quietly pulled the effort following a private conference proving unable to secure enough votes within his ranks.

Private sources say that several GOP House members are afraid to be seen siding with banks over the people. An undisclosed Congressman stated, "We're looking down the scope of complicated numbers for the midterms and Clark continues to surprise us, so it's best if we just ride this one out."

Meanwhile, the Supreme Court has declined to issue further comments. Legal observers note that the judiciary lacks the cards to wage a war on the executive. The U.S. Marshal Service, responsible for enforcing the Court's decisions, remains under the control of the Justice Department, which the President has a firm hand on.

As the branches of government prepare for a first shot, what remains clear is that the moratorium on foreclosures will stay in place following the President's political gamble, which redraws the lines of Executive Power.

By ZEKE MILLER

"In times of crisis, we do not shirk our respect for one another. We join together to take hold of a future that is rightfully ours."— President Wesley Clark, Davos 2009

American sovereignty is under attack from a rogue globalist vision perpetrated by President Wesley Clark, the former NATO general turned Democratic golden boy. Flanked by internationalist elites, prissy bankers, climate bureaucrats, and IMF kingpins, Clark hailed the work of none other than British Prime Minister Gordon Brown, yes, that same architect of the UK's spend all you can give bailout binge for his "visionary leadership" during the 2008 financial crisis.

Clark-Brown Pact: The Globalist Pie in The Sky

Climate agreements bound by executive order

Kyle Doyle - Economist with an Opinion on everything Experienced in government and diplomacy Author has 2.6K answers and 789.3K answer views Updated 3m

Resigning is putting the events nicely. It's safe to say that Republicans have not been able to heal the wounds left by the 2008 election disaster. NPR: President McCain hails Libyan Rebels as "Heroes"

By Mike Holtz

March 4, 2011

The President made remarks that drew criticism while on a trip through Benghazi to establish diplomatic ties with the rebellion government. The rebels have found their champion to offer support in their quest to topple Colonel Moammar Gaddafi.

President John McCain (Republican, Arizona): I've met these brave fighters who are not al-Qaida. They are Libyan patriots.

Such remarks have raised criticism about the necessity of aiding the rebels in the same vein the United States S. did in the 1980s with the mujahideen battling the Russians in Afghanistan. Some of those fighters Washington helped arm and train in Afghanistan later joined al-Qaeda. The President dismissed the criticism, saying that none of the leaders had any ties to radical Islam in their history.

Many within the President's inner circle have floated the idea of sending ground troops to Libya. While President McCain has made no assertions, he has made it clear that the United States will support the National Transitional Council in Benghazi to avert a possible stalemate.

President McCain: I'll be very frank. I do worry that if there is a stalemate here, it could open the door to radical Islamic fundamentalism because of the frustration that thousands and thousands of young people would feel as if they are deprived of participating in democracy in the united Libya.

The President has drastically increased NATO air strikes, deployed Predator drones to Libya, and refused calls to take the A10 and the AC130 out of combat. Amid low approval ratings stirred by McCain's legislative failures to reform social security and the second PATRIOT Act, it seems the President has turned all of his focus outward.


More From NPR
What does the Vice President's "Sqeeze Gaddafi" remark mean for the future of the administration's Libyan policy? (Jan 9th 2011)

Former President Clark lambasts McCain's escalation of the Libyan conflict in a CNN interview. (Feb 14th 2011)

How McCain's right flank intends to cripple the President's reelection campaign. (Feb 20th 2011)

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/FDShEaw.png'})]) } if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 2) { // mitt 2012 e.pages.push(`

TheViewFrom32: Undecided? Try the Match-O-Matic

If you don't know who to vote for in the 2012 elections and are having a hard time keeping track of who said what among the 11 candidates, help is here. ABC News and USA Today have created the Match-O-Matic, a cheery little game that asks you a handful of questions about the Economy, Immigration, Health Care and Hot Topics (gay marriage, taxation, global warming, and a candidate's experience) before spitting out a list of three candidates whose views are closest to yours. A scorecard on the side shows where you agreed and disagreed, and displays a short quote from the candidate addressing each issue.

The first time I tried, I answered as honestly as I could, without trying to influence the choice in a more liberal or conservative direction. That gave me Tom Steyer, Bernie Sanders and Caroline Kennedy as 1-2-3.

I tried again, this time being a bit more "realistic"—meaning conservative—with my answers. This time I got Joe Sestak, Tom Daschle and Rod Blagojevich.

Unfortunately the site says nothing about the methodology behind the game other than a statement that appears briefly on one screen that says "Answers gathered from statements and speeches by candidates and catalogued by USA Today." Not a very enlightening explanation of the research behind the game.

The final question on experience annoys me. Here are your choices:

What if I have no preference, or want both "U.S. Senate" and "served in military," or "has run a business" and "served as governor or mayor"? No go.

I don't know how heavily this question is weighted, but you can see that a single answer can push your choice toward a specific candidate.

So, is this anything more than a fun way to spend a few minutes on a Monday night? Actually, I think it is. I never gave a thought to Tom Steyer or Joe Sestak, but now I'm going to learn more about them. Sadly, of course, none of my top three candidates have a snowball's chance in hell of being on the ballot.

If you want more than a fun, painless suggestion on who to vote for, try the VoteMatch quiz instead. It's not as slick but is much more thoughtful. The questions are similar, but you give your answer on a scale of 1 to 5, from "Support" to "Oppose." Each question links to a detailed explanation of the topic, explaining what each answer means, giving background information and defining "buzzwords" often tossed around when the topic is discussed.

VoteMatch quiz results screen Steyer was at the top of my list again, but Clinton popped up at number two, and there's Caroline Kennedy again, coming in third.

You can answer the questions as quickly as with Match-O-Matic, maybe even faster because you don't have to wait for spiffy graphics to update. You can also take your time and read extensive background information on the questions and on the candidates when you get your results.

The site is quite transparent about its content and staff. Staff members are named, with a bit of information about each. You can find links to the source material used to determine a candidate's position on an issue. Steyer, for example, has listed 17 quotes on the Environment, 5 on Economic Equality, and 2 on Healthcare. Blagojevich has 26 on Anti Corruption, 10 on Crime, and 20 on Taxes. As Illinois Governor, his record on these topics are also shown.

Most importantly, for each possible answer in the VoteMatch quiz you can see exactly what statement by the candidate was used to determine his/her position as well as the number of points the answer is worth. Much more helpful than the "behind the green curtain" approach of Match-O-Matic. Give them both a try and let us know how it works out by clicking "Comments" below.

Update (October 30, 2012)It's hard to believe that anyone might be undecided after all the publicity about both candidates, but just in case... I've explained my reasons for voting for Steyer in an essay titled What if?

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/D4xNls5.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 3) { // jeb tpp e.pages.push(`

Larry King Live CNN: Trump flirts with a presidential run, citing the President's "Abandonment of Hardworking Americans."

Real estate mogul and reality TV host Donald Trump went on Larry King Live to advertise the 10th season of The Apprentice, which is coming later this year. While discussing the details of the season, he commented on the Bush Administration's failures to lift Americans out of the hole left by the 2008 recession. Later, revealing that the season's theme was "Second Chances," referring to the fact that the 2008 recession impacted all the contestants.

He later went into a rant about the Bush Administration's efforts in combating China by "selling the American worker," as Trump put it. He claimed Bush was letting the world "eat our lunch" by signing free trade deals screwing over the American auto industry and farm industry.

President Bush, who championed the agreements with India, Japan, and the Philippines to combat Chinese economic prowess, has stood by his efforts, calling them "necessary deals to keep America in the lead." Trump's worldview is quite different, as he later tore apart NATO allies for not meeting the minimum military spending requirement.

King asked, "Why don't you make a run for President then?"

Trump replied, "I've been thinking about it and if I did I would campaign for American workers which naturally aligns me with the Democrats. I'm a friend of these people and a lot of them want me to run and if I did I believe I'd win."

"Then why don't you?" King pressed once more.

"If I do it, I'll win, Democrats win and America wins." Trump replied.

"So will you run?" King asked for a final time.

Trump replied, "We'll see."

Trump has seemingly opened the door to run in the 2012 Democratic primaries, which would press him against New York Senator Hillary Clinton, North Carolina Senator John Edwards, Former House Majority Leader from Missouri Dick Gephardt, and Independent Senator Bernie of Vermont.

His decision of whether or not he will run is not taken seriously by most Democrats, but he remains insistent that only he can beat Bush.

FOX: Democrat prepare to sack Hillary as a final rebuke of the Clinton years

By Jim Kelly

TV Host Donald J. Trump took the debate stage by storm last night, listing off his grievances about Democratic frontrunner, Senator Hillary Clinton, calling her a "Republican at heart" and a "warmonger." Senator Clinton has come under fire from many other Democratic opponents like John Edwards for working too closely with the Bush administration.

Mr. Trump then went into a tirade, lambasting President Bush, claiming he was a "no show on the job" getting paid to go on vacations abroad and asking, "Why would you pay a man $400,000 a year for a no-show job?" Much of the reality TV host's candidacy has been orbiting President Bush's failures to protect the American worker from "immigrants taking our jobs" and his push for free trade deals that "sell American farmers out."

The once-crowded field of establishment Democratic candidates has slowly dwindled after Trump's surprising victory in Iowa and the New Hampshire upset outcome of Senator Bernie Sanders taking the plurality. This effectively handicaps Senator Hillary Clinton's campaign as the candidates prepare to enter the South Carolina contest in what may decide who the next Democratic nominee will be.

Of those who remain, Former House Majority Leader Gephardt, after placing fourth in Iowa, many wonder why he's chosen to remain in the race, with many suspecting he hopes to revive his campaign at South Carolina or make a bid for VP of one of the mainline candidates.

While Senator Bernie Sanders polls poorly in most primaries leading up to Super Tuesday, he may drop out and throw his support behind Trump as an anti-establishment last stand.

Trump is expected to perform admirably in South Carolina, but if Edwards becomes the frontrunner in the long term, he may be in for a tough time.

Senator Clinton stands the most bruised in the race as most expected her to take the New Hampshire Primary with relative ease, now must place all her bets on beating Edwards in South Carolina.

John Edwards appears to be the front runner in waiting, and with Clinton's campaign is faltering, her defeat here can effectively boot her out of the race. If Edwards can secure the position as the last man with any ties to the establishment left, he'd enjoy frontrunner status and be able to watch as Trump and Sanders fizzle out by Super Tuesday.

Polls predict an Edwards victory after campaigning heavily with leaders of the black community in South Carolina.

34-37% Edwards

26-28% Clinton

15-18% Trump

12-14% Sanders

5-9% Gephardt

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/FDShEaw.png'})]) } if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 4) { // rice quizz e.pages.push(`

The Washington Post: 4th-grader quizzes Rice on the War in Iraq

By Alec MacGillis

Washington Post Staff Writer

February 4, 2010

Days after justifying an emergency troop surge to Stanford University, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice was again pressed by a 4th-grade student at Washington School on her role in sending more troops to Baghdad.

She stroked up controversy when asked to comment on President Giuliani's handling of what she called an "Iraqi civil war," which she had blamed former President Wesley Clark for allowing to take place.

Rice, in her first appearance in Washington since returning home from her visit to Baghdad, attended the Jewish Primary Day School of the Nation's Capital before giving an evening lecture at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue.

The questions were developed beforehand by students and were not screened by the Secretary. They started innocently, asking what it was like growing up in segregated Birmingham, Alabama, until they took a darker tone.

Misha Lerner, a student from Bethesda, asked the Secretary what she thought of the casualty rate of U.S. troops skyrocketing after President Giuliani's proposed troop surge went into effect.

The Secretary coldly stated, "It's a sad necessity following the disastrous state in which President Clark left the country."

She added: "I hope you understand that it was a very difficult time. We were all so terrified of another attack on the country. September 11 was the worst day of my life in government, watching 3,000 Americans die. Even under those most difficult circumstances, the president was not prepared to do something illegal, and I hope people understand that we were trying to protect the country."

Misha's mother warned the Secretary that the question her son had was even tougher, "Are you going to end the war so people stop dying?"

"Nothing within President Giuliani's authority as Commander in Chief is off the table and we're doing everything we can to ensure this conflict comes to a swift conclusion soon. We will not abandon Iraq under any circumstances but we will look into alternative methods to wage war on terror to ensure another 9/11 never happens again."

The remarks drew criticism, with most claiming Secretary Rice alluded to the nuclear option. She has disavowed these claims and reiterated that the United States military only seeks conventional warfare methods.

2009 Washington Post Company

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/x4pIEwj.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 5 && Win > 5) { // rudycare e.pages.push(`

VICE News In Search of a Jewish Ron Paul Supporter

[Opening shot: Rapid-cut montage of Hasidic men walking, yellow school buses pulling up, Yiddish storefronts, a kid spinning a dreidel in slow motion. Klezmer music plays, before it suddenly cuts off with a record scratch.]

VICE News Presents

“In Search of a Jewish Ron Paul Supporter”

Reporter: Leah Goldstein

[Cut to Leah standing in the middle of a crowded street in Borough Park.]

LEAH (to camera):

We live in a world where Ron Paul is President. For two years in office, the main story was about gold, liberty, trying and failing to abolish the Fed. During that time, he was garden-variety unpopular, and perhaps the only interesting thing about him was the extent to which he lost in the midterms, with the Democrats winning a whopping 280 House seats and flipping the Senate. But then, after the fact, he gave a speech on the results. You already know what we’re about to play.

[Hard cut to clip of RON PAUL at a rally, shouting at a podium.]

RON PAUL:

There is a Jewish cabal that’s running this country! The banks, the media, the war machine, they’re all in it! I'm just saying what everyone else is afraid to say!

[Cut back to Leah in disbelief.]

LEAH:

So yeah, that happened. Since then, Paul’s approval rating has been bad, really bad. But, in what I’m sure isn’t a great surprise, his approval rating among American Jews dropped to one percent. Not ten. One. That’s statistically… basically zero. But still, there’s someone out there, one person somewhere who responded to a poll and identified as a Jew, that supports Ron Paul. That’s like your bubbie liking Mel Gibson’s films after reading the transcript of his arrest, or your rabbi coming out as a really big Henry Ford admirer.

So today, I’m wandering around New York’s Jewish neighborhoods, trying to find the one Jew who still supports Ron Paul.

[Montage: Leah asking elderly Hasidic men, hipster Jews in Williamsburg, Israeli expats, Chabad rabbis. Everyone shakes their head, waves her off, or starts yelling in Yiddish.]

ELDERLY MAN (Hasidic, subtitled):

Ron Paul is… meshuggeneh. He wants to destroy the dollar and give us all chickens!

YOUNG WOMAN (Modern Orthodox):

I would rather vote for a Hezbollah candidate before I vote for him. That man said the Mossad had, what was it, “puppets in the deep state.”

SECULAR GUY IN A “Yeshiva University Intramural Champs” sweatshirt:

He blamed the 2008 crash on "Jewish Goldman Sachs banking voodoo." I mean, he used those words. He’s doubled down on everything.

SHAWARMA STAND GUY:

He said the Six-Day War was a CIA operation. You believe that garbage? Get out of here with your camera.

[LEAH, walking briskly down the street, half-laughing into the mic.]

LEAH:

Okay, it's been four hours. I’ve had six different people tell me I’m doing “a chillul Hashem” just for asking about Ron Paul. Two guys accused me of being Mossad. Another woman thought I was doing a spiel for Purim. I had one guy claim that I needed to check my mother’s ancestry a little closer after I confirmed that yes, I am actually Jewish. I had maybe 20 people tell me to fuck off.

[Cut: Leah ducks into a narrow alley near a used clothing shop and a Judaica store. She sees a man with a crocheted kippah holding a copy of The Revolution: A Manifesto.]

LEAH (to camera, whispering):

Wait. Wait. Oh my God.

LEAH (approaching):

Hey. Hi. Sorry. Are you reading… is that Ron Paul?

MAN:

Yeah.

LEAH:

You… support him?

MAN:

Hell yeah. He's the only honest politician left.

LEAH (disbelieving):

But, like–he literally said there’s a “Jewish cabal” running the country. That’s not–like–that’s not ambiguous.

MAN:

I mean, he’s not wrong. It’s not like he made it up. He’s just saying what the Jews need to hear.

LEAH (V.O.):

His name is Mordy Rosenblatt. He’s 62. Lives in his sister’s basement in Midwood. Used to be a software engineer. He voted for Paul in 2008, but only because he was dissatisfied with Clark and wanted a fresh face to deal with the recession. He first became a real Paul supporter in 2009 after someone on a survivalist message board sent him a PDF about the gold standard. Says he took all his money out of the bank in 2010 and now only trades in silver and honey.

[Cut back to interview. Mordy is now animated.]

MORDY:

The media turned on him because he said the quiet part out loud. We know there’s influence. Look around. You’ve got AIPAC, ADL, Goldman Sachs. You think the average goy in Iowa doesn't notice that?

LEAH:

But… you’re Jewish. You’re saying we’re too powerful? Like, you and I, a reporter and an unemployed guy on the streets of New York, we’re too powerful.

MORDY:

No, I’m saying the truth hurts. Just because you and I aren’t personally represented in the cabal doesn’t mean that there’s not a cabal. Look, Ron Paul isn't an antisemite. He’s a pro-truth-about-semites. And us Jews have always hated the overly truthful. Look what we did to the prophets.

LEAH (blinking):

You're comparing Ron Paul… to Jeremiah?

MORDY:

Absolutely.

LEAH:

But don’t you think that Paul might pose a threat to you, with the rhetoric he’s using? Hate crimes have gone up.

MORDY (shrugs):

I’m just saying, Maimonides would have voted for him if he knew about fiat currency.

[Leah turns to the camera, completely dumbfounded.]

LEAH:

I honestly don’t know what to say anymore.

[Cut to montage of Mordy showing Leah his sister’s backyard, where there’s a metal bunker half-buried under a sukkah frame. He eagerly presents her with jars of preserved butter and gold coins. He shows her around his room, which is surprisingly put-together, and pulls out a copy of the Talmud with notes written in the margins in red ink: “FED = PHARAOH.”]

MORDY:

The Torah says “You shall have just weights and measures.” That’s gold, not paper. This is all halachic, you understand?

LEAH:

Sure.

[Final segment. Leah sits on a bench, exhausted.]

LEAH (to camera):

So there you have it. I found him. Perhaps the only Jewish Ron Paul supporter. I don’t think I understand him. I’m not sure he understands him. But yet, he exists. He’s real. He walks among us. He thinks the IRS is a front for Catholic-Hasidic collaboration. And honestly, I’m not going to argue with him, because he offered me dried beef and then quoted both Hayek and the Rambam in the same sentence.

Anyway, even though his reelection prospects might look dim, Ron Paul can rest easy knowing that he still has one supporter left in New York. Mazel tov.

[End credits roll over distorted klezmer music remixed with audio from Ron Paul speeches.]

IMDB Kitchen Nightmares episode 4: Hell In a Cardboard Box.

Summary

Gordon heads to Phoenix, Arizona, where he visits "Simple Jack's Food in a Box," an American bistro run by locals Jack King and his wife, Anna King, who reveal the shocking state of the restaurant industry in Arizona.

The restaurant resides in a dreary cardboard box after Jack King's original restaurant went bust in 2008. Still recovering from the wounds of the depression, Jack founded Simple Jack's Food in a Box from a cardboard box he picked up outside an out-of-business Pizza Hut.

Unfortunately, since the restaurant's launch, the King family's business has failed to break even, and they called Gordon Ramsay to help save their failing restaurant.

Chef Ramsay is greeted by two stubborn and depressed owners who are reluctant to change their ways. When the Michelin-starred chef faces off against Jack King, the dynamic threatens to make this the first Kitchen Nightmare that Gordon can't save.

Quotes:

"Either you start listening to me or I'm out of here there's plenty more restaurants run from porta potties and lemonade stands that can use my help."

"This place reeks of more sorrow than a fucking Goodwill."

The Young Turks: Republicans Are Going To Lose

Look, I don't think I need to tell you this, but here's a prediction: Democrats are going to pummel Republicans in a couple of months. The map is going to shift blue at a rate never before seen. Senate seats like Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Indiana are all up for the president, who has a historically low approval rating in all three.

Republicans have begun to be president, and, as we will show, you have relegated Paul to small crowds while on the trial. Most humiliatingly, though, during the president's most recent stops, he found himself tied down to his failed attempt at killing social security. Let's go to clip number 7 for that.

CUTS TO VIDEO OF RON PAUL SPEAKING TO SENIOR VOTERS

—

"President Paul how can we trust you? How do you expect us to trust you after you tried to gut millions of benefits from Americans in need?"

PAUL: Our Founding Fathers never intended for the government to be responsible for so much bloat. The deficit is unsustainable, and so is the long-term solvency of the program you know as Social Security.

"But we need it to live, we have a right to that money!"

PAUL: When we get into the nitty gritty about rights, human rights are subjective. I look at things from a clinical perspective. It allows me to make the hard decisions that no one else is willing to make.

"So what stops us from voting against your plans in the upcoming midterms?"

PAUL: Nothing, I suppose, but for your own sake and the sake of your children, you must realize that everyone is going to die. Everyone—

—

CUTS BACK TO CENK

—

Well, you heard it here, folks. We're all going to die, so why not accept it? My God, I have not heard such great wisdom from a Republican in a long time. A doctor, even Christ. I mean, what are we doing here? Are they trying to lose?

See, these assholes are down by at least 15 nationwide, and the stunt President Paul pulled trying to kill the program that, which, let's face it, predominantly benefits Republican voters, is an ingenious path to a Democratic victory in these upcoming midterms.

I don't want to hear about any Wesley Clark comebacks, either. I want a genuine, hardened progressive like Sherrod Brown or Russ Feingold to jump on the political scene. These guys have what it takes to end this sick joke.

FOX: President FURIOUS over AIG bonus bailout

By Andrew Scott

American International Group was saved while on the brink of collapse during the 2008 Great Recession by then President Clark's administration and at the time it was justified as a “non-negotiable” to save the economy. Now just a year later The Washington Post has broken the story that AIG plans to use part of the bailout funds to payout over 165 million dollars worth of bonuses to 400 employees.

The outrage stirred by multiple news organizations like The New York Times which reminded us “the same business unit that brought the company to the brink of collapse last year.” National outrage over an almost comical situation followed the story's landfall. President Huckabee has propelled himself to the forefront of this outrage threatening executive action against AIG if it were to follow through with these bonus bailouts. “America had to foot the bill for your mistakes and now you want to use that money to pat yourselves on the back for a good job?” Huckabee said when addressing the controversy.

It's a strange unifying movement behind the outrage between the left and right with Independent and self proclaimed socialist Senator Bernie Sanders passionately denouncing the scandal. Many are advocating that President Huckabee go after AIG and force them to repay the bailouts by the end of the year. Huckabee has flirted with the idea and also debated shutting down all government agencies used to bailout private firms and businesses.

Arguments in favor of AIG's position state that AIG would have trouble attracting and retaining talent “if employees believe their compensation is subject to continued and arbitrary adjustment by the U.S. Treasury.” The Huckabee Administration has found thus totally unacceptable and signaled that action against the bonuses will be taken in some form.

Related Articles

Impeachment? Democrats cry as Huckabee ramps up the gas on a constitutional reformation. (May 4th 2010)
Secretary of Treasury Rush Limbaugh? Huckabee jokes but how likely is this? (April 11th 2010)
Huckabee infrastructure projects, where the money is going and is the president really putting his face on money forwarded to them? (March 22nd 2010)

NBC NEWS: Mother of gay South Carolina teen who died by suicide claims his school participated in his untimely demise.

August 12, 2010, 12:57 PM EDT / Updated August 12, 2010, 6:53 PM EDT

By Janet Griffin

The mother of a recently passed gay teen alleges school and government played a part in the death of her son. She gave her public statement statement to NBC News reporters here:

"After my son passed, I learned that he had several discussions about homosexuality with school administrators and was told that being gay was a choice, he was told that he was making a mistake. My son is dead, he wasn't a mistake, he wasn't making a choice and you are the people responsible for this. When the Vice President stands for bullying, when our President demonizes people for their sexuality, this is the result. Are you happy now, was it worth it, all you propagandists telling the world that people, kids like my son are dangerous? Just so you can pass some fucking amendment? Well guess what you got your wish, my son is dead, you killed my son President Brownback. I hope you're fucking happy."

Sadly, This news is one of many we've witnessed in the last few months. Mrs. James was gracious enough to share the note left behind from her son. Please be advised of its dark content.

"Dear Mom, I'm writing this to say goodbye and hopefully help give you comfort. Thank you for giving me life, I don't want you to cry, I need you to be strong. You were an amazing mother, nothing you could do would have changed my decision. I just can't handle it anymore, the name calling, the bullying it all hurts. If it was only that I could stay strong but I feel wrong, I'm able to ignore it most times but they make me feel so weak. They constantly tell me I'm a mistake, I don't know who found out I was gay but the rumor spread around the whole school and I feel other kids are constantly watching me. My friends won't talk to me anymore and when I tried to bring it up with Mrs. Shelby told me being gay was a choice. I don't know how I made the choice but I feel wrong and I just want everything to go back to normal. I want to be normal, but I can't. I don't know why I'm like this. Tell Alice she can have my room and that I'll miss her a lot. I'll miss you a lot mom, I want you to know that. This isn't your fault. It's mine. Goodbye."

Seeing the number of stories we're seeing come through is horrifying. Anti-bullying and gay rights activists have joined forces to protest and advocate for legislation and the repeal of the Federal Marriage Amendment. These tragedies make the case more apparent than ever. We need to do better, America; we need to be a kinder and more accepting nation.

The Guardian: China's economy to overtake U.S. in next two years, says OECD.

Josephine Moulds

According to a leading international think tank, China will overtake the U.S. economy in the next two years and become the largest economy in the world by 2013.

The Paris-based Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) said that due to the U.S. economy hitting its 7th consecutive quarter of GDP decline since President Brownback's "Great American Tax Experiment," China can overtake the U.S. economy by the end of 2012. Asa Johansson, senior economist at the OECD, said: "It is quite a shift in the balance of economic power we are going to see in the future."

The tax cuts were the largest in American history and caused massive budget shortfalls. To save the economy, the Republican House cut deep into education and transportation spending, which received an equally large backlash. When the 2010 midterms came, the massive majority Republicans held in both the Senate and House was obliterated. Now facing a volatile Democratic caucus, President Brownback has stubbornly barked at any reversal of his policies.

The global shockwave of the 2007-2008 global financial crash allowed this development's conditions to take place. Although the crash also hit China, the U.S. hit more significant downturns, and President Brownback's government mismanagement has turned what was once a recession into a full-scale depression, the likes of which hasn't been seen since the 1930s.

A bipartisan coalition is forming in the House and Senate, and it seeks to repeal most of the President's tax cuts despite his assurances that a bright future is ahead of the country. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi led the movements to repeal the tax cuts shortly after the 2010 midterms saw Democrats retake the House in a strong rebuke of the President. Whether repealing the tax cuts can reverse China's emergence as the world's leading economy remains to be seen.

Thu 2 Jan 2011 07.11 EST

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/nOt4KoF.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Neo > 6 && Troops > 0) { // 1944 e.pages.push(`

The Intercept_: California Supreme Court strikes down President Clark's executive order, stopping the creation of internment camps for "radical Muslims."

By Murtaza Hussain

President Clark made history weeks ago when he signed Executive Order 13767, which effectively revived internment camps styled after those used in WW2.

The executive order was crafted in response to the Charlottesville shooting in which eight civilians were killed in what was later labeled a domestic terrorist attack. President Clark justified the decision at a press conference where he stated:

"If these people are radicalized and they don't support the United States and they are disloyal to the United States as a matter of principle, fine. It's their right and it's our right and obligation to segregate them from the normal community for the duration of the conflict, if someone supported Nazi Germany at the expense of the United States, we didn't say that was freedom of speech, we put him in a camp, they were prisoners of war."

This was in response to heavy criticism of his decision to remain in Iraq and Afghanistan and expand drone warfare, taking out targets in Pakistan and Syria. With mass protests at home and abroad, he's faced intense scrutiny from many within his own party, who call for the President to back down from this hill.

Multiple courts across the country immediately questioned the executive order's legality and put it to the test, halting the creation of a single camp. Now, in a 6-1 decision, the teeth of the executive order have essentially been pulled before it could even be put into action.

The entire debacle has become a political bruise for the President, with most of his party distancing themselves from his decision.

ABOUT

SUPPORT US

NEWSLETTER

CBS NEWS: The Humanitarian Crisis in Syria is one of President Clark's making."

August 27, 2011, 3:42 PM ET

Under President Wesley Clark's command, the United States Air Force conducted a bombing campaign of the Assad Regime. The strategic bombing of chemical weapons sites was meant to halt and prevent their usage.

Bashar al-Assad's regime ordered the use of chemical weapons in the mass revolt and protests affecting his nation and many other Arab countries in the wider Arab Spring, which had deposed many other regimes like his. President Clark had warned Assad that he would come down on him twice as hard if he threw out international law. Assad called Clark's buff and didn't hesitate to act to prevent a disaster.

However, the large-scale bombing reflective of the president's style in the Kosovo war has backfired tenfold with a chemical disaster at multiple government sites leading to mass civilian displacement and sickness throughout various sites close to Damascus: a military base in the Dimas area, army depots in the eastern Qalamoun; the Kiswah area, where Iran is believed to have been building a base; and a site in the Qasioun hills, and a research center in Masyaf. Reports from the town of Khan Sheikhoun say that more than 80 people were killed in a chemical explosion.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has condemned the Western strikes "in the most serious way." The Syrian Civil War has become a quasi-proxy war between the United States and Russia, with most Democrats joining in with President Clark's rhetoric warning of a "Second Cold War."

Other critics of the United States' actions in Syria lambast the president as a fearmonger. Many within the Republican Party have even begun to denounce neoliberalism at work, with the emergence of the Tea Party Movement advocating for a more isolationist foreign policy.


CBS Coverage
Senator John McCain lambasts the president's handling of the conflict in Syria as "poorly planned" (Feb 4th 2010)

Can Bachmann pull off an upset, primarying Pawlenty? (Feb 14th 2010)

Shrouded in failure, can Landrieu fight her way into a term of her own? (Feb 20th 2010)

CNN NEWS: Petraeus touts the Afghani army and police force as "increasingly credible."

by Jeanne Sahadi

Among calls for a withdrawal plan from Iraq lay the confused and aimless effort in Afghanistan. Long overshadowed by its unpopular brother, the war in Afghanistan has remained an afterthought of the Clark Administration, floating a timed withdrawal but refusing to commit to anything of substance.

Now, In the latest of General David Petraeus's "charm campaigns," he's stood by Afghanistan and denounced any ideas of a withdrawal from the region by 2013 as the Clark Administration has floated. The general has taken it upon himself to focus on the internal improvements of the Afghan army. He also described how they were steadily taking more responsibility from NATO allies.

President Clark's unpopularity with his left flank demanding he pull back from Iraq and Afghanistan has sent cryptic messages in a clear attempt to buy time for the public to get over it. Secretary of State John Kerry, who stayed on for the job despite repeated disagreements with the President's conduct, has been equally left washed ashore as word spreads of a possible resignation is looming.

Secretary Kerry has disavowed the claims, but his isolation from the rest of the State Department gives him all the reason to call it quits despite his high public approval. Insider sources claim the Secretary is aloof at times, and his lowbrow approach is unable to make much headway in an increasingly stubborn administration.

General Petraeus, on the other hand, is the hands-on type who seemingly has full control over the situation in Iraq and Afghanistan. With much speculation over a possible presidential run circling the media, he's also reaffirmed that he has no intention of running for the Republican Presidential nomination in 2012.
