Bankruptcy F.C.

Bankruptcy F.C. is a British television sitcom, created by Matt Berry and Arthur Matthews, starring Berry as George Dross, a banker at Barclays who must take his charity football league seriously when the bank collapses during the Global Recession. The sitcom was critically acclaimed and earned Berry the 2012 BAFTA Award for Best Male Comedy Performance.

Series 1 (2011)

Episode 1:

George comes home from work at Barclays to learn that his entire company has crashed due to its acquisition of Lehman Brothers, with George having been part of the Lehman Brothers acquisition team. Out of a job, he is despondent about his chances, as his association with Lehman brothers makes him a banking pariah. However, George realizes that Barclays has submitted a team to a charity football league with a prize of $300,000 pounds, which goes to the charity of the winning team’s captain’s choosing.

The next day, George officially joins the team, not revealing his true intentions to the rest of the players. When one of the players has to withdraw due to an STD, George recruits his sister Miranda, a professional pole-vaulter and all-around athlete, to the team. The team wins their first match after George and Miranda become embroiled in an argument on the field, distracting most of the players and allowing the Barclays striker to walk home the winning goal.

Episode 2:

George’s teammate Devin, also unemployed, undergoes a divorce after his wife learns that he spent all of the couple’s money on cleats for the team. George and Miranda attempt to cheer Devin up by hiring a call girl, but things go haywire when the call girl turns out to be extremely attractive and intelligent, causing Devin to consider immediately starting a relationship with her.

After learning that he hired the call girl before their divorce was finalized, Devin’s wife forces him to publicly humiliate himself in a series of embarrassing tasks on the streets of London so that she doesn’t use it for leverage in their divorce settlement. George and Miranda attempt to re-contact the call girl to warn her to stay away from Devin, but to no avail. In the team’s game, although they face the prospect of a draw against a weaker side, Devin sees the call girl in the stands and she flashes her breasts at him, giving him the courage to convert a bicycle kick from outside the goalie box, winning the game.

Episode 3:

While manipulating a friend into buying him an expensive lunch, George learns that many of the bankers have orchestrated golden parachutes for themselves in case of Barclays’ failure, leaving them unscathed by the collapse. Infuriated, George starts an argument with his old boss, which accidentally leads to the old boss, drunk and angry, falling out of the restaurant to his death. George is then arrested for manslaughter.

Due largely to George’s imprisonment, the team loses the next game. Miranda attempts to contact the boss’ family in order to explain what had happened, but is unable to locate a single family member who speaks of him positively. In a last-ditch effort, Miranda attends his funeral, but finds herself accidentally conducting the entire ceremony. After the ceremony, Miranda locates the boss’ only child, Lyudmila, the result of the boss’ “obsession with Ukrainian hookers.” Miranda is able to seduce Lyudmila and get her to advocate for George, leading to him being released from jail after a set of wild adventures behind bars.

Episode 4:

While looking for a fish and chips shop that he can actually afford, George accidentally wanders into a sketchy part of London and finds himself inside an illegal bookie’s shop. The bookie recognizes George from a story about Lehman Brothers’ failure and offers him a deal to throw the league’s games in exchange for more money than he could earn from winning the league. George gladly accepts, though the bookie warns him that there will be hell to pay should he fail.

At the team’s next game, George tries his best to lose purposefully, but Miranda, with Lyudmila cheering her on, has the game of her life and scores a hat-trick, winning the game handily. George fearfully tries to evade the bookie’s men, as they are accidentally incapacitated one by one while trying to locate him. Finally, the bookie himself finds and threatens to stab George while the two of them are in Trafalgar Square. However, the bookie’s exaggerated mannerisms and clothing, alongside George’s boisterous counters, convince the crowd that the two of them are acting out a live performance. The crowd showers them with money, allowing the bookie to cover his losses and George to escape intact.

Episode 5:

The team loses a heartbreaker of a match, making the league’s last game an all-or-nothing affair. In search of a spark of inspiration for the team, George announces a surprise trip to Washington D.C. after winning a televised prize competition whose reward is British Airways miles. The team is excited to visit America, but soon learns that it was not all they had hoped it would be, as despair and political polarization are omnipresent on the Washington streets.

George realizes that the team is despondent and almost certain to lose their next game, and decides to cheer them up by taking them to a cultural exchange program held at the Kennedy Center, where the British team can take joy in their favorite pastime of belittling Americans. While the team is midway through the cultural program, finding little success, the American President (a fictionalized version of Wesley Clark, played by Anthony Head) drops by as a surprise guest. George, still upset at the U.S. government for allowing Lehman brothers to fail, tears into the President for his economic missteps, pointing to his dreadful approval rating and causing him to cry in front of the team. Realizing that George went too far, Miranda comforts him one-on-one, and cheers him back up by talking about his past bombing Serbians and how she, as a Brit, thinks that “Mike Jackson is an idiot.” The newly cheerful President gives a roaring pep talk, breathing new life into the team.

Episode 6:

The team faces its toughest opponent yet in the charity league: HSBC UK, which has now replaced Barclays as the largest bank in Britain. In the first half, the HSBC team races out to a 3-1 lead over Barclays, with their players openly mocking the Barclays team for being out of a job. At halftime, the team is ready to give up, but George reminds them how much more money they have at stake than the employed HSBC team does. This realization sparks the team to new heights, and they dominate the second half, with George assisting Miranda on a header to win the game and league in stoppage time.

Upon being presented with the winner’s check, George announces his plans to donate it to the “Doss Liberation Fund,” and vanishes from the rest of the squad. A flashback set two months later shows George, Miranda, and Lyudmila on the beach in Greece, where they marvel at how affordable the country has become for them after its debt crisis. George takes a phone call from a former team member demanding to know where the money is, but laughs and hangs up before toasting the two women, who toast back.

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/fY6hlCC.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Troops > 0 && Russia > 2) { // low neolib while troop surge e.pages.push(`

IN BETWEEN TWO FERNS STUDIO - TWO CHAIRS, TWO FERNS AND DIPLOMATIC GENIUS

ZACH GALIFIANAKIS:

My guest today is America's four-star General, Ulysses S. Grant, except he's sober and replaces the bottle with drone strikes, Wesley Clark, everybody.

PRESIDENT CLARK:

Thank you, Zach. Always a pleasure.

ZACH:

So how's Iraq? Still on fire?

CLARK:

Significant progress has been made. This is a strategic process that requires precision.

ZACH:

Yeah, I heard the exit strategy comes in an installment plan. Does that require me to pay interest by voting for Landrieu in 2012?

CLARK:

It's a comprehensive process.

ZACH:

Indeed, you've been called an "abrasive hawk." Would you say you prefer diplomacy or just making John Kerry weep?

CLARK:

Diplomacy is only as strong as its backer.

ZACH:

That's a fun phrase. Like "pacifist Mike Tyson" sounds peaceful, but he still caves my nose in when I look at him wrongly.

CLARK:

Peace requires strength.

ZACH:

You were famously caught bad-mouthing the Iraqi prime minister on a hot mic. Would you say you enjoy making the CIA's job in getting rid of him harder

CLARK:

Let's not make jokes like that. The moment in question was highly edited.

ZACH:

Yeah, I understand I make off-the-cuff comments too, but mine usually don't end up turning Baghdad into a Mad Max set.

CLARK:

Heard.

ZACH:

So are you able to tell the difference between an Iraqi and an Afghan child before they become a civilian casualty, or do you pinch the numbers after the fact?

CLARK:

Audible sigh

ZACH:

Just kidding, we all know their crayons of mass destruction are the real targets.

CLARK:

You done?

ZACH:

Did you say the same to Putin when he had his foot on Georgia's throat?

CLARK:

The situation in Georgia was a precarious issue, and we did everything we could.

ZACH:

You appear tense, if it makes you feel any better, we offer gift baskets with a map of Russian population centers for reference.

CLARK:

No, thanks.

ZACH (leaning in):

Tell me this, if you were to go with a presidential catchphrase, would it be "we're sorry" or "God, please, please, please, just let the dow have a good week."

CLARK (sighs deeply):

Let's just go with "Ready to leave" both Iraq and this interview.

ZACH:

Ouch, I'd take that personally if you weren't a soulless robot. Would you mind if I pricked your thumb to prove you have blood?

AWKWARD SILENCE

ZACH:

Well, this has been Between Two Ferns with my guest, President Wesley Clark, expert in diplomacy and fireworks enthusiast.

CLARK:

Thank you, Zach.

ZACH:

Next week, former Secretary of State John Kerry will teach us how not to cry during a UN briefing.

Fade out.

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/VBcOyL0.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Notroops > 0 && Russia > 2) { // low neolib while troop surge e.pages.push(`

Excerpt from HBO's "HeartBroken" Stand Up Special by George Carlin

Liberals always give me a good laugh. They make a big stink of things and then get into power sniffing the same shit they complained about!

They always march around wagging the finger, 'Oh no you can't do that, Mr. President, we shouldn't have invaded Iraq' while they voted for it and practically made American soldiers residents there for a decade. That's how we got President Wesley Clark. Oh, you remember him? How could you not? He's on TV every day sporting his same PowerPoint patriotism and the promise of fixing American wars that won the day over that moron Bush.

It sounded good, right? "No more wars." "We'll finally finish the ones we got." "Fenito!"

So what does he do now after finally pulling us from Iraq? A big ole military U-turn sending more fresh meat—oh, I mean soldiers into Afghanistan to fight off an incoming Taliban resurgence. Oh, what you didn't hear about that? Well, that's because it doesn't exist! The Taliban is still just hiding in the mountains while America attempts to hold out in the longest staring contest ever before seen!

That's like robbing a bank and putting the money back nicely, only to walk into a second one wearing a bomb vest and screaming, "We got momentum now."

Oh, you want the reason? Stability, strategy, suicide vests, sand. Whatever it doesn't matter, we're in for the long haul, holding metal detectors over the desert, hoping to find the lucky pot of democracy Bush Jr. was so adamant about finding.

So President Clark, General Clark, Commander Clark, or whatever title he's parading around with this week, decided that we needed to go back to war, or else the war would travel across the Atlantic and beat us in a game of poker or something.

What I can tell you is that I'd rather focus on the wars I'm fighting here—fighting with Comcast and my damn landlord.

But hey, that's the American way we were all taught as young kids. We go to war for peace, we kill to protect human rights, and we drop democracy out of the back of a B-52.

Wesley Clark didn't change how we fought wars; he just found a way to make them look more pretty—by wearing stars and ribbons.

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/lHMz00B.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Notroops > 0 && Blair == 1) { // low neolib while troop surge e.pages.push(`

BBC NEWS: How Tony Blair Came to Be So Unpopular

By James Naughtie

Special Correspondent, Radio 4 News

9 July 2010

---

A Fall Few Could Have Predicted

If you went back in time to 1997 and told the average Brit that the super-star icon who had swept them off their feet and to the polls would be where he is now, they'd have a good laugh. Now, as we live history in the moment, there are cheers and laughs. Tony Blair has marched his party into an early grave due to his ego and hopes to regain his stolen valor from his previous failings.

---

Collapse from Within

Echoing shock and horror from the Blair campaign headquarters only served to further question where the Prime Minister believed he was taking his party. It's not like polls ever favored his chances or his ability to claim victory. After Chancellor Brown's dramatic exit in late 2009 following the announcement of Blair's intentions to run for another term, the Labour Party began to spiral out of stability and grace.

---

From Magic to Missteps

When Blair triumphed over Major in a stunning rebuke of Thatcherism, the world clapped as near magic swept through the country. Welcomed by President Bill Clinton, their relationship grew strong with diplomatic ties that would further expand to George W. Bush.

That is where the trouble began. When the September 11th attacks struck the heart of America, Blair stood by Bush as a showing of solidarity. He then followed Bush into both Afghanistan and, more controversially, Iraq—sinking British credibility on the American promise that Saddam Hussain held nuclear capabilities.

When the Bush administration came up short in providing evidence for such claims, so did Blair.

---

The Magnetism of Controversy

From then on, controversy would stick to Blair like a magnet, and despite coming out of the 2005 election victorious, the Labour Party was stung by the losses. The magic that captivated the country was rapidly dissipating, and rumors of a rift between Prime Minister Blair and Chancellor Brown circled the media.

It was then Blair was offered a blessing: General Wesley Clark had stormed onto the American political scene, decapitating the Bush administration before it could cause him any more trouble. President Clark won the 2004 election on the promise that he would bring a change in strategy to Iraq. That change would be a firm withdrawal deadline, offering Blair political room to wiggle around Brown's threats of resigning and continuing his premiership.

---

Iraq, Again, and the Temptation of a Fourth Term

Working closely with President Clark, they handled Iraq and all of its controversy together. Withdrawing from Iraq would become Blair's championing policy—which apparently made him pursue an ambitious fourth term.

Speculation that Blair would call the election in mid-to-late 2009 caught the Conservative Party flat footed, and polls showed a possible Blair victory at hand if the election were to be called.

What Blair hadn't expected was the fury from Chancellor Gordon Brown, who expected him to step aside for the party's sake. Brown resigned, causing a total meltdown within the Labour Party and effectively killing Blair's hope to call an election early—with Labour MPs loudly against it.

---

The Beginning of the End

So Blair had to watch his potential victory squandered by an unwilling Labour Party. David Cameron's Conservative Party would then rebound in the polls after the good feelings from the Iraq withdrawal faded and the economic woes returned.

Blair slowly marched through the end of 2009 to 2010, deeply scarred by Brown's exit. Remaining determined to ride out the general election despite horrific polling across the provinces, he charged at the poor circumstances head-on—now promising a continuation of the economic recovery from the 2008 recession.

Meanwhile, David Cameron effectively poised himself as a change leader who would end the chaos brought through the 2000s. As the past decade and the next came to clash, Cameron proved himself a winning bet as his party trounced over Blair's in a landslide—the final rebuke to the long-running Labour Party rule under Blair.

---

The Final Report Card

The election marked itself as a performance report for Prime Minister Tony Blair, a report which would come very negative for him and his party. Tony Blair would then concede, ending Labour's dominance and allowing a Conservative vision to take the 2010s by storm.

Reuters: Recession declared over by NBER

The Business Cycle Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research met yesterday by conference call. At its meeting, the committee determined a trough in business activity in the US economy in June 2010. The trough marks the end of the recession that began in December 2007 and the beginning of an expansion.

The recession's length exceeded most economists' expectations following the sudden collapse of General Motors due to Congressional deadlock, which prevented any economic bailout of these corporations. Just two of the many American financial institutions collapsed during the heat of the recession in 2008 and would later be followed by the collapse of AIG, "American International Group" in February 2009."

President Wesley Clark, frustrated by the lack of action, chastised Congress often following his reelection and made it his first priority to break the congressional deadlock, eventually breaking a deal of a 450 Billion stimulus bill that established the TARP program, which would be used to bail out Bank of America.

The committee's declaration of the end of a recession does not mean that the economy has recovered. Most institutions have yet to get back on their feet, and most families across America still feel the effects of the recession.

The declaration was followed by President Clark, who stated, "Economists may believe the recession has ended, but American families are still struggling to pay their bills day to day, and it's our job to offer more relief to the American people. The Republican Congress begs to differ, with most Republican leadership opposing further aid, citing the budget.

"Due to the lack of improvement in the labor market, particularly the stubbornly high unemployment rate, the recovery still feels like a recession to many households," said Harm Bandholz, chief U.S. economist at UniCredit Research in New York. "The NBER does not seem to be too enthusiastic about the economic outlook either."

Editing by John Estler

Our Standards:
The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/3EkRyt5.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Econ == 3) { // suicide e.pages.push(`

NBC: Home Owners Loan Corporation becomes a mountain of success for the Republicans to climb over.

Updated March 4, 2011, 11:49 PM EST By NBC News

President Clark's resurrection of the Home Owners Loan Corporation amid the 2008 financial crisis was a drastic solution, and to most at the time, it was necessary. The bill, which reestablished the corporation along with a 1.1 trillion dollar bailout, was put forward by Senator Hillary Clinton (New York) and was credited for the late surge in President Clark's re-election polling and eventual victory over his Republican opponent.

Today, the corporation accounts for nearly 15 percent of owner-occupied nonfarm mortgages. Many credit it as a necessary lifeline to millions of families across the United States.

However, Republican primary candidates feel much differently. Governor Rick Perry (Texas) has taken the lead in the discussion, blaming President Clark's "destructive homeownership policies" as the leading cause of the housing crisis. Other candidates like former Senator Rick Santorum, who ran in the 2008 Republican primaries, tend to agree. In particular, Santorum has been scrutinized after taking out a loan with the corporation himself when a tax assessment of his $2 million, five-acre home fell 25% in value. The former Senator's polling has dropped after the revelation came to light.

President Clark and the Democratic Party have stood by the corporation and hailed it as a success despite the sluggish economy. Vice President Landrieu has staked part of her presidential campaign on allowing the corporation to continue its work in the face of Republican calls to disband it.

As Democrats pick up the pieces of the steep losses during the midterms, the corporation's results have become a beacon of light for the party to coalesce around. It's hard to deny that the message "We kept you in your homes" isn't powerful. Republican deficit hawks claim billions of dollars are wasted within the corporation's work, but polls show at least 55% of Americans approve of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, while 39% disapprove and 6% are unsure.

`) e.executable.push([3, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/rOepdV2.png'})]) } // 2011 if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 4) { // rice quizz e.pages.push(`

From Reddit: President Condoleezza Rice and Vice President Giuliani at Madison Square Garden Rally, STILL NO SIGHTING OF MIKE PENCE!!!!

u/libertarians

u/mayoforsam

I know it's a tired joke, but seriously, where the hell is Mike Pence? I'm starting to miss the days when I could turn on my TV to watch President Giuliani's press conferences, where Pence would fan him with a giant feather while Condi fed him fruits until he'd occasionally answer a question about the invasion of Libya.

It was good entertainment hearing the president bring up 9/11 while justifying why we needed to bulldoze another random country. So what happened? Where's the shop bitch of the White House?

Secretary Rice is the one we get to see the most since she's the one busy covering for Giuliani's ass. All those failures in Libya? Benghazi? Please, Giuliani is a celebrity posing as the "acting president" now. Anyone with a brain and two working eyes can see that given State Department goon, John Kerry is the Democrat's pick for president, it's obvious that Rudy's incompetent foreign agenda has brought back old feuds.

This is a battle of foreign policy intellect, and Condoleezza Rice is in the hot seat, facing off against low approval ratings and Kerry being a popular face of the State Department. The media haven't picked up the sidelining of Pence, but it's pretty clear that his role in the administration is slowly being diminished in favor of laying the groundwork for President Rice's third term in 2016.

I wouldn't be confident in her shoes since most issues give Kerry the upper hand because Giuliani's inept economic policies have done nothing for American families.

Still, I'll be kicking up my feet no matter which deep-state puppet wins. Don't blame me; I'm voting for Randall Terry.

Esquire: Vice President Lieberman announces he will not run for reelection in 2012.

FOX: Democrat prepare to sack Hillary as a final rebuke of the Clinton years

By Jim Kelly

TV Host Donald J. Trump took the debate stage by storm last night, listing off his grievances about Democratic frontrunner, Senator Hillary Clinton, calling her a "Republican at heart" and a "warmonger." Senator Clinton has come under fire from many other Democratic opponents like John Edwards for working too closely with the Bush administration.

This effectively handicaps Senator Hillary Clinton's campaign as the candidates prepare to enter the South Carolina contest in what may decide who the next Democratic nominee will be.

Senator Clinton stands the most bruised in the race as most expected her to take the New Hampshire Primary with relative ease, now must place all her bets on beating Edwards in South Carolina.

John Edwards appears to be the front runner in waiting, and with Clinton's campaign is faltering, her defeat here can effectively boot her out of the race. Ben Garrison Found Dead in Montana Home

Rich Mims

Daily Inter Lake

November 8, 2012

LAKESIDE, MONTANA– Ben Garrison, a political cartoonist and illustrator who rose to prominence in 2010 for his deep-seated admiration for President Ron Paul, was found dead in his home in Lakeside, Montana from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Garrison, who died at age 55, was found at home by his wife Tina, who had left the house to run errands.

Garrison, who was raised in Washington and Texas, received a B.A. in art before working as an artist for the San Angelo Standard Times and the Seattle Post-Intelligencer before moving to Montana in 2009. Garrison, who considered himself a libertarian and voted for Ron Paul in 2008, began drawing politician cartoons shortly after his move to Montana, inspired by the “negative perception of Ron Paul in the media.” Garrison began posting political cartoons on his website and on political message boards.

Garrison’s political cartoons, which followed a general libertarian and right-wing theme, often made references to conspiracy theories and fringe politics, with various commentators describing them as sexist, racist, anti-feminist, xenophobic, anti-government, and anti-semitic. Garrison had a noted love of President Paul, however, whom he often depicted as an extremely vibrant, strong, muscular fighter in contrast to the real-life Paul’s advanced age and normal build.

In 2010, Garrison attracted national attention for his cartoon entitled “Tyranny of the Minority,” depicting Republican Maine Senator Olympia Snowe and Democratic Illinois Senator Dick Durbin stabbing President Paul in the back while dressed in togas, inside a Roman-style building with the words “Global Elitist Headquarters” written on it. The cartoon was posted thousands of times on the internet and was even covered by mainstream news outlets, who noted the humorous level of agony on Paul’s face. Following the success of the cartoon, Garrison was able to focus on political cartooning full-time, even scoring an invite to the White House and a personal meeting with Paul in 2011.

In the months leading up to Garrison’s death, he often expressed deep anxiety over the prospect of an Obama presidency, and donated a substantial amount of money to the Montana Republican Party to unsuccessfully keep Obama from flipping the state. In the days leading up to his death, Garrison’s comics became more extreme and conspiratorial, with Garrison insisting that a Paul reelection was the only way to avoid a national catastrophe, with his wife claiming that Garrison had a mental breakdown on Election Day after Obama’s landslide 14-point victory.

At the moment, Lakeside police are ruling Garrison’s death a suicide, pointing to the ballistic results showing no evidence of foul play and a lengthy suicide note next to Garrison’s body matching his handwriting, in which he claimed that he could not live any more due to the prospect of an “African globalist” winning the presidency and his “brave Texan knight” being defeated. Garrison’s wife has set up a link to fund his funeral on his personal website, as well as a thank-you message to his fans.

`) e.executable.push([4, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/gPi7T53.png'})]) } if ( quickstats[0] <= 269 && Dem == 5) { // paul floppenig e.pages.push(`

Politico: Three primaries are in, and President Paul has failed to take one

Jack Wells

President Ron Paul's tenure in the Oval Office has become nothing short of disastrous for the Republican Party. From the downward spiral of an economic recession to a full-scale depression, the task put on his shoulders would never be easy. This isn't to say that he hadn't dug his own political grave somewhat. From the collapse of banks nationwide and the eventual axing of key government programs and agencies, his name soon became political poison as Republicans down-ballot attempted to run away from the political landfall of his collapsing mandate.

Following the disastrous midterms, among the first to announce their intentions to stop President Paul's renomination was House Minority Leader Eric Cantor. Running on a promise to return the Republican Party to "responsible conservativism," his announcement seemingly opened the door for a whole band of kooks and nuts. Most surprising was the entrance of now-fired General Stanley McChrystal, who ran on a promise of returning the United States to NATO.

President Paul shifted focus on reelection soon after declaring his intentions to run as a Republican again. However, as the campaign began, attacks came down on his rule from every angle. Cantor focused on fiscal irresponsibility, McChrystal concentrated on foreign policy failures, and former Judge Roy Moore went after Paul for his social libertarianism. When the major candidates came to blows at Iowa, Paul suffered a humiliating first defeat at the hands of McChrystal, who beat him in the suffering farm state by nearly 6 points. The President continued his quest to keep the presidency but would soon be shockingly defeated in New Hampshire, falling third place behind Cantor and McChrystal.

Following two defeats, his chances looked especially grim as South Carolina quickly approached. Moore, who focused heavily on winning the state, led polls by 3 points over McChrystal, while Paul trailed by over 6%. Polls proved correct as Moore took the state by storm while Paul continued to rant about his party's betrayal.

So, where does this campaign move from here? Many have floated ideas, such as Paul relinquishing part of his administration to the establishment and possibly even dropping Vice President Johnson to claw back support. However, one door remained open on Paul's path until November 6th. Paul has refused to state whether he'd consider running independent if he failed to get renominated by the Republican Party. If he were to go down this route, he'd almost assuredly be throwing the election to former President Wesley Clark, who has seemingly become the frontrunner of the Democratic Primaries after beating Sanders in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

Related Articles

Clark and Landrieu again or is the former president looking for new blood? (March 4th 2012)
Libertarian Party pledges support for the President will he run with them? (Feb 11th 2012)
Vice President Johnson noticeably tired at press briefing. (March 1st 2012)

THE O'REILLY FACTOR – JANUARY 26, 2011

Opening Segment: "You Call That Bipartisanship?"

Cue theme music

BILL O'REILLY (visibly annoyed):

Okay. Last night, President Thompson, a hardworking and decent family man, by the way, addressed the nation at the State of the Union, harboring words of bipartisanship and extending an olive branch to the other side of the aisle. What do Democrats do?

They pretend they are sleeping. I'm not joking. They sat back in their taxpayer-funded seats and closed their eyes like toddlers refusing to eat their vegetables while the President of the United States spoke to them and the nation.

This entire messy affair was enough already, and Democratic leadership is always talking up a big game about moving forward and dropping partisanship for the sake of the American people, and these frauds snub the President on live TV!

This ridiculous charade was a performance act. Don't kid yourself; these folks were not protesting for the sake of the American people; they were capitalizing on President Thompson's decision for the greater good of the American people.

Had he let the impeachment trial take its course, the Senate and the House would likely have conceded the charges of bribery and misappropriation of public funding.

Unfortunately, we do not live in a just or fair world. We are forsaken to behold a radical Democratic Congress make a fool of themselves and run away scott-free without a damn nickel's worth of punishment.

America needs a reality check, and who better to give it than the competent and respected President of the United States?

The Democratic memo to the American people is that accountability is worthless as long as you can point to another guy and say he's worse.

SAINT PAUL, MINNESOTA– During his latest campaign rally, President Huckabee announced that in his next term, he plans to force Muslim-Americans to identify themselves by wearing a star and crescent patch that will be stitched onto their clothing. SNL Title: White House Game Night Gets Ugly

Title: White House Game Night Gets Ugly Setting:

The packed Oval Office

Wesley Clark – The President who recently had a mental breakdown after witnessing Russia conduct a complete takeover of Ukraine and the new Republic of Latgalians People's Republic(breakaway state from Latvia) (played by the host Jon Hamm)

Mary Landrieu – The Skeptical Vice President attempting to smooth over relations(Rebel Wilson)

John Kerry – Soon to be retired Secretary of State, completely done with the administration, one foot out the door(Seth Meyers)

Hillary Clinton – The gossip girl who can't wait to get her foot in the door of this administration and hopefully sideline the vice president (Amy Poehler)

—

WHITE HOUSE. OVAL OFFICE – NIGHT

(Clark paces back and forth, rubbing his temple and mumbling utter nonsense while Landrieu quietly enters the office)

MARY

Uh… hi. Are you okay… Mr. President?

WESLEY (without looking up)

Mr. President… yeah, that's me, Mr. Terrible PR-esident, Mr. Failure, Mr. Can't Catch a Break!

MARY (nervous laugh)

Mr. President, uh.. what are you doing with that box full of guns?

WESLEY (finally looks up)

MARY

Sir, are those real guns in there?

(Wesley pulls a real fucking AK-47 out of the box, holding it like a trophy.)

WESLEY

Well, yes, you see, I couldn't get my hands on Laser Tag equipment in time, so I just took a trip down to Texas. And oh, you know the kids down there, they sell guns like they sell lemonade.

(Secretary John Kerry enters the room, and Clark jokingly shoots at the floor in front of him)

JOHN (startled)

What? What the hell are you doing?

MARY (eyes wide)

Mr. President, you should put the weapon down; that's dangerous.

(Hillary Clinton walks forward from the wall behind them, revealing herself covered in makeup of the same color as the wall.)

HILLARY

Oh, don't be such a stiff, Mary. If I were still living in the South, I'd have my hands on guns like these all the time. I'll always miss the days using Bill for target practice.

WESLEY (smirking)

See, she gets it, Mary! You better start following the new groove around here, or I'll consider endorsing her in 2012 haha.

(Dramatic thunder sound effect. Lights flicker.)

MARY

Yes sir! Will do!

(Mary grabs a gun from the box and shoots at John, nearly grazing his skin)

JOHN

Ah! Dammit, Mary, that could have killed me!

HILLARY (rolls her eyes)

Oh, John, your career has been dead for years. What will your actual death do to change the world?

(Just then, the doorbell dings..)

WESLEY

Oh, that must be the Prime Minister and the rest of my cabinet. Hopefully, they got the memo for this meeting.

(The four begin putting on the bulletproof vests and other equipment)

Mary

Are these vests safe to shoot at?

HILLARY

Let's test it!

(Hillary shoots Mary in the dead center of her chest)

MARY (groans in pain on the floor)

Ow! Are you trying to kill me?

HILLARY

I might be~

WESLEY (calmly)

Alright, get ready, folks, 'cause I'm not holding back on any of you.

BBC: The "Who Done It?" of our generation, who bombed the Nord Stream Pipeline?

18 hours ago

Kelly Agner BBC News

At midnight on October 11th, 2010, an explosion was heard from the fabled Nord Stream Pipeline being created to pump Russian gas into Europe. With ongoing investigations, I will look into the possible culprits of the attack.

Suspect #1: The Americans

American opposition to the Nord Stream pipeline creation was not some hidden secret. From its very signing under Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, President Wesley Clark forewarned the deal to pump Russian gas to Germany's ports via the Nord Stream 1 pipeline as an easy bargaining chip for Russia to wage when needed. After the Russo-Georgian war had gone underway, the American President made it his goal to give NATO its next purpose. Hardened by his experience fighting in the Vietnam War, Wesley Clark became a preacher of the Second Cold War, which had begun. At a NATO summit in Brussels, Clark brought up the famed Nord Stream pipeline that was near completion and labeled it a "geopolitical weapon," not a pipeline. So when the pipeline exploded last month, it was only natural for the country labeling Putin as the "Russian menace" to come under suspicion.

Suspect #2: The Russians

It's no secret that after Wesley Clark's victory in the 2004 United States presidential election, Putin had prepared to deal with a hostile Western Hemisphere. General Clark was famed for his career saving Kosovo from the vilified Serbians, a close brother nation to Russia. It is well known that Clark nearly brought the conflict to a worldwide affair by ordering troops to engage Russian troops at Pristina Airport, and if not for insubordination in his ranks, none of us would be here right now. From the first moment Clark took his seat in the Oval Office, he made wariness of the threat posed by Russia a headline at every opportunity. So Putin might have chosen to pull the plug on this project, given the strange unity between NATO nations.

Suspect #3: Al-Qaeda

Still reeling from the death of their ring leader, Osama Bin Laden, the terrorist organization has been a key suspect floated by both the United States and Russia as the culprit. Given the tension between the two countries, many suspect the terrorists behind 9/11 were hoping to reignite it to get the two powers to throw their weight at each other. Al-Qaeda has hopes to shake attention from both the United States in Iraq and Russia's interest in Syria. It's not impossible to imagine that they'd go to these lengths to achieve those ends.

We will likely not know who was behind this bombing until investigations by both Germany and Russia conclude, but nobody is above suspicion.

Second Cold War or another round of cheating puffing? (Jan 22nd 2011)

The New York Times: Did Libya Secretly Influence Elections in the West? Gaddafi's Explosive Claims Stir Global Controversy.

By [Lisa Fargo]

May 23, 2011

TRIPOLI—The international scene has recently erupted due to Libyan Dictator Muammar Gaddafi's claims of donating money to influence various Western elections, spurring a political upheaval in those countries. The most damning claims were made against U.S. President Wesley Clark and French President Nicholas Sarkozy, whom Gaddafi stated to have donated money toward their respective elections in 2008 and 2007. As both leaders attempt to fight the fires brought about by these claims, Gaddafi continues to fight for the soul of his nation, with the ongoing Libyan Revolution threatening his position.

Are his claims valid? No one can say for sure now, but opposition leaders in France and the United States have come forward demanding an investigation. President Clark, whose turbulent 2008 reelection bid victory had been attributed to his leadership in dealing with the economic crisis, is now under speculation for foreign influence. Clark, who made a point that the situation in Libya needs to be handled delicately, faces allegations that he's too close to Gaddafi. The election interference claims now serve to further muddy the waters he treads, but there is no concrete evidence to say that the Clark campaign used or received any funds from Libya. Congressional Republican leaders have called to open an impeachment inquiry to "collect the facts properly," but Democrats remain at the President's defense.

Sarkozy, however, faces a much greater challenge as the 2012 French presidential election looms over his mandate like a storm. The claims that he took funds from Libya hold more weight with the opposition since, following his 2007 victory, he pursued a policy of detente with Libya. The recent reversal of Sarkozy's Libya policy has put the President under fire for "trying to save face" and avoid an investigation.

Since 2007, both the United States and France have sought to deepen ties with both leaders, hoping to undo the frosty relations of the early 2000s, but this scandal serves to uproot such progress. The socialist opposition in France has repeatedly attacked President Clark as a divisive force on the national stage. Their qualms lie in the President's policy in dealing with conflicts like the Russo-Georgian war and the declining relations between Ukraine and Russia. If Sarkozy were to be ousted, President Clark's united NATO dream could be soiled by a socialist fire breather taking the reins in France.

For now, the world watches as two presidents attempt to cleanse the aroma of controversy without losing the mandate they rule by.

Washington Dispatch: President Clark sets fire to the international briefing by referencing the "No Russian" Video Game mission.

By Edward Anthony | Washington Dispatch | November 26th 2011

SCATHING - In a moment that blindsided the entire world, President Wesley Clark appeared to reference the notorious video game mission "No Russian" from Call Of Duty: Modern Warfare 3. The American President offered a scathing rebuke at a United Nations international panel, claiming that the mission would "teach Russia a lesson" about the cultural consequences of authoritarianism.

The remarks were not pre-planned, and the President had deviated from the planned address due to the Russian Federation's advances against Ukraine's most eastern territories. Starting off ranting about the moral bankruptcy of the Russian Federation, and quickly ad-libbed into controversial territory.

"The Russian Federations glorification and usage of the sympathy card is pathetic," Clark said. "If Putin wants to test the limits of civilization and world order he should expect the cultural division he creates to mount in greater depth than this 'No Russian' video game could ever hope to accomplish."

The mission in question, in which players participate in a fictional mass shooting at a Russian airport, garnered widespread international condemnation. The mission is not present in copies of the game sold in Germany, Poland, and Russia.

After the speech, Russian Ambassador Victor Vitaly Churkin condemned the remarks as an "insane provocation" that glorified terrorism through the veil of moral high ground.

Social media criticism ballooned with hashtags like #NoRussianGate and #WesleyMakarov trending.

The White House Press Secretary would later issue a clarification:

"The President wasn't condoning any acts of violence against Russia or its people. The President stands by nations threatened by Russian aggression and stated that if Russia continued to provide international condemnation, sympathy would be hard to come by.

The Kremlin has demanded a heartfelt apology, but reports claim that the President has no intention of backing down.

Vanity Fair: Hot Russ Summer

Beyond the Midwestern humility and bona fide Wisconsinite authentication resides a hot icon on the national scene. Russ Feingold isn't just running for president, he's barreling through the process with calm composure that swoops the delegates off their feet. While the incumbent president can't find a date for prom on election night, Feingold has baskets full of options to choose from as his number two.

John McCain's predicament couldn't get any more dire while his campaign struggles to find a poor sap willing to join him on a certain death March to defeat. The summer season couldn't get any more optimistic and excited for Feingold's sure bet victory. The president attempted to besmirch his opponent's name through fear of the Russ Gust of Wind blowing national security away.

Well, did the fear work?

No, because an American heart throb isn't taken down by fear tactics when he makes ethics look like a cover of Vogue Magazine. McCain rolled back the American Dream, and Russ is the man promising to roll it up and mass produce it like toilet paper for all Americans to benefit from.

The phones don't ring with the Feingold jingle just from looks alone, although when put on a dating show, old Johnny would struggle to escape last place. No, the Feingold campaign dances with Americans with the same idealism that brought us FDR and John Kennedy. The sexual interest isn't in the slick back hair or night rider shades, but Feingold's promise to make things better at a time when the McCain administration has few hopeful things to say.

Replacing the cut, cut, and roll back rhetoric on social security or Medicaid, he promises bold action on healthcare. It's not called Hot Russ Summer because we want him under our bed sheets (although few would say no to that), it's called that because America wants to feel hot, happy, and hopeful once again. Russ Feingold is the man for the moment.

Does Wesley Clark actually know who Mary Landrieu is?

by Jill Frame

August 28, 2012 | Daily Kos

New Orleans, LA - The floor was vibrating, and the cheers and hollering echoed across the convention hall.

Former President Wesley Clark took the stage at the DNC last night to thunderous applause, delivering a stinging shellacking of President McCain's "foreign policy coup." He condemned the interventions in Libya and Syria, and commented on the erosion of global trust in American prowess and the lagging economy.

"I warned you, the Republican Party since the dawn of the Bush administration would perform a coup of American foreign policy. Seven wars in seven years, we are living it. President McCain must be stopped."

Thank you, Mr President, or so we thought.

"That's why I'm proud to present to you my friend and former Vice President Mary Landrieu to be your next president of the United States of America!"

Wait what? Mary Landrieu? You make that speech as a way of drumming up support for the same Mary Landrieu who backed McCain's security strikes on Iran? The same woman who gave a soft endorsement to the killing of Assad? The former Vice President who voted for the Iraq war as Senator?

Are we talking about the same Landrieu? When I rub my eyes, I still see the same woman who stayed silent when asked for a response to President McCain's Second Patriot Act, which essentially killed internet privacy.

We are speaking about a candidate who, as Vice President, reportedly disagreed with every single decision her President made regarding delivering justice on the national stage and pulling away from Iraq, restoring our rights to privacy, and attacking the neoconservative thought experiment.

Clark is throwing his weight behind her. I understand his loyalty, but lying for her is unacceptable.

Unless the President is living on another planet, his speech directly contradicts the beliefs and policies of Landrieu.

Let's not forget where we've come from.

Mary Landrieu, whatever her strengths, has never been a dove, or even on that wavelength whatsoever. She's a centrist at best and a diet Republican at worst. She was Clark's Vice President and made a name for herself as the counterbalance to progressive ideals.

The elephant in the convention hall remained prevalent. The Clark-Landrieu administration was a missed opportunity in many ways, and the former President's pick for President today is among the worst aspects of that era. Mary Landrieu's triangulation and caution personified.

If we are to believe that Clark puts his money where his mouth is, then he should at the very least propel a progressive stalwart to Landrieu's flank. Whether it's Feingold or Obama, the people demand credibility on progress.

Progressives need to ask themselves this: Will Mary Landrieu speak first to them, or become another cautionary tale of governing out of fear of becoming another Wesley Clark?

ABC NEWS: Vice President Landrieu gets a pass from gay rights activists as she flies to a steady victory in a presidential debate.

By Jessica Wilde

The first presidential debate took place last night and was primarily focused on domestic issues, including the recent Supreme Court decision Obergefell v. Hodges legalizing gay marriage across the United States.

Vice President Landrieu, who had been silent on the issue, finally took a strong stance, stating, "My personal views have evolved quite a bit, but I am happy the Supreme Court came to this decision and would enforce it as president." This came in stark contrast to former Senator Rick Santorum's response, who disavowed the decision and reiterated his support for traditional marriage.

With polls showing a majority of Americans supporting the decision, it was expected the Republican nominee would focus more on the economy. However, with a steady recovery from the 2008 recession, the Vice President was able to box him in multiple times during the debate, not showing any weakness, much like her performances in previous vice presidential debates.

However, the worst hadn't come to the former Senator when the newly reestablished Home Owners' Loan Corporation topic became the final nail in the coffin. Senator Santorum had called for the corporation's disbandment throughout the campaign and reiterated his intentions to disband it upon assuming office.

When the moderator asked the Vice President's view of the corporation, she stated, "I would continue the Corporation's operations so every American can benefit from mortgage bailouts like the one the former Senator took on his 2 million dollar mansion." The remark drew loud applause, and as polls show, Landrieu won the debate by similar margins that she has led Santorum across this campaign.

Jeffness Blogging: Doom-and-Gloomberg

Nothing surpasses my sheer disappointment more than seeing Republican primary returns nowadays. Every day I'm forced to hear Republicans shout, "THIS IS THE GUY WHO CAN DEFEAT MARY LANDRIEU!" Yes, I'm guilty of it just as much as anyone else, but seriously, Floridians chose to back Mayor Michael Bloomberg? I'm tired of hearing this because NO, this is not the best man suited to close the chapter on Democratic dominance, and I'm not willing to play into delusions.

And so the benchwarmer candidates are beginning to peel away from their runs for president, hoping to either secure the moderate banner of the Republican Party with Bloomberg or hitch a last-ditch effort to stop him by backing Michelle Bachmann's Bible backed bid. Huntsman, Perry, and Paul are looking more flimsy by the day, so it's only a matter of time until they cash out.

Here's where all the fan boys of fat fuck Haley Barbour will come in, saying he's gonna surge in the polls. Holy hell, he came in fourth in Iowa. He's undoubtedly the answer America is looking for! I don't give a damn about loser candidates. Last time I checked, there was no bronze medal given out for coming in fourth place. Let's not hype up clowns like this.

Begrudgingly, I'm beginning to accept that independent minds like mine are never going to get our voices heard in politics. I'm sure as hell not going to back bat shit crazy Bachmann and her "blessed by the lord" run for president. I'm all for a woman running for president, but damn crazy like that lady might just make me vote for Landrieu instead.

Well, here we are at our only "viable" choice left on the table. Michael Bloomberg. If you forced me to describe my feelings for his candidacy in just a few sentences, I'd come to you with this.

● Bloomberg is nearly a Democrat in Republican clothing; he and Vice President Mary Landrieu widely agree on most issues, and where they differ is on issues like the environment or immigration, where more often than not, the Democrats sound more conservative!

● His candidacy is sitting ducks when it comes to trade and confronting China. While the Clark administration has taken a very confrontational position on China's growing economic problems, Bloomberg is screaming the need for "detente." If Landrieu were to push him on this during the general election, she'd stomp him like a BUG.

● His response to Clark's "New York Money Men" gaffe essentially cemented his candidacy as a front-running man able to combat the administration's reluctance to stand by Israel, briefly garnering the applause of folks like Mike Huckabee.

● Maybe… MAYBE you can convince at least five people in the Deep South that he's a true conservative. Just maybe five people who sleep under a rock can be fooled into thinking that the New Yorker really speaks for their social conservative cause.

● Hear me out, but maybe a Republican can win out in the urban centers, I'd surely be interested in seeing that map.

As always, I've reserved my admiration for any candidates once they prove themselves on the national stage. Who knows, maybe Mike is the man able to take the GOP out of its perpetual state of comatose, or he'll sink them again just for Karl Rove to rant and rave about how the numbers coming out of Bowling Green, Kentucky, or Nashville, Tennessee, are incorrect and that the voting machines have got it wrong!

I have very little faith that President Bloomberg is a real possibility, and unlike Michele Bachmann's fans, I'm not willing to blindly follow what my gut tells me.

Wikipedia: Controversies of the 2012 United States Presidential Election

The controversies of the 2012 United States Presidential election involved both Democratic incumbent vice president Mary Landrieu and her Republican opponent Virginia Senator George Allen. However, a majority of these controversies negatively impacted Allen and are believed to have contributed to his defeat in the November election.

^Allen's gaffe referring to Landrieu's pick for Vice President Barack Obama as one of “those people”

^Landrieu's claim that climate change was a privileged peoples problem

^Allen's stance that a woman “wasn't prepared to be president”

^Allen supporters attacking Code Pink protesters

^Landrieu gaffe referring to herself as “the black candidate”

^Allen arrest warrant controversy

^Screaming match between Barack Obama and Bobby Jindal at Vice Presidential debate

^Landrieu campaign fined for misappropriation of funds used for a personal flight

^Allen claim that Trent Lott's Strom Thurmond praise scandal was overblown

^Twitter intimidation

^Wesley Clark's “New York Money Men” gaffe

^Allen caught staring at Landrieu's breasts at first presidential debate

^Landrieu claim that unpopularity of her running mate Barack Obama was due to racism

^Allen caught politicizing over Hurricane Sandy as being an “October Surprise” to worry about

Talking Points Memo: Limbaugh shares concerns about 2012 election

By Matt Shuham

October 24, 2012, 4:13 p.m.

Start your day with TPM.

Sign up for the Morning Memo newsletter.

Conservative shock jock Rush Limbaugh warned Cain supporters not to assume polls showing the GOP nominee losing was "rigged," offering insight to Cain supporters frustrated by the Republican candidates' poor polling against Vice President Landrieu.

"I wish that I could sit here and tell you that I, without question, think the polls are rigged. I have thought so in previous elections," Limbaugh said Monday on his radio show.

Limbaugh admitted that he made a similar mistake in underestimating the support of Wesley Clark 4 years ago.

"In 2008, honest to God, folks, I thought Wes was gonna lose by ten or fifteen. There weren't any polls that said that. I thought they were all using an incorrect turnout sample," Limbaugh said. "The way I was looking at it was that because the economy went belly up voters would naturally see our solutions as more viable. Turns out they never did and Clark was able to prove himself."

What skews expectations this time around is the controversy surrounding Cain while still holding a tight grip over the Republican base. By contrast, Landrieu, who remains in a comfortable position in the polls, faces problems such as a lack of enthusiasm, making people wonder if the turnout is set to drop this year. "If that's the case this year," the Los Angeles Times' David Lauter wrote in August, "then acknowledging Republican turnout advantage against Democrats would probably boost Cain's standing by a point or two."

Republican Herman Cain sports the Tea Party credentials, hoping to lead the movement to an explosive victory like the rapid congressional gains made by Republicans in the 2010 midterms. Landrieu has stuck by her credentials in bipartisanship and a continuation of the recovering economy credited to the administration's handling of the recession.

In 2008, as the campaign season hit its final stretch, Limbaugh often told his supporters that polls were biased toward Clark.

"They are designed to do exactly what I have warned you to be vigilant about, and that is to depress you and suppress your vote," Limbaugh said in late October 2008 when commenting on a CBS/New York Times poll and a Washington Post poll which slightly favored the president. "These two polls today are designed to convince everybody this election is over."

Today, though, as the 2012 election is well underway, Limbaugh confesses his doubts and offers sage advice for Cain supporters to remain vigilant. "It's a risk here to just throw the polls out and say they don't matter because you end up creating a false reality for yourself that isn't true."

Start your day with TPM.

Sign up for the Morning Memo newsletter.

`) e.executable.push([5, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/sZkiEBf.png'})]) } else if ( quickstats[0] >= 269 && Econ < 3 && Neo > 3) { // e.pages.push(`

ABC: Republican nominee for President thinks vaccines cause autism?

Al Harrison || ABC Editor

July 1st 2012

As part of an attack on the Clark Administration's vaccine policies, particularly regarding the sexually transmitted disease HPV, which can lead to cervical cancer, the Republican nominee for President, Michele Bachmann, claimed that a woman told her after a Republican debate that the HPV vaccine had caused her daughter to develop "mental retardation".

The attack is based on the longstanding myths of vaccines causing learning deficiencies. The "gaffe" was followed by multiple public opinion polls showing Bachmann's support had severely dropped as the post-convention excitement had seemingly vanished for the Congresswoman.

Vice President Landrieu's early ad campaign also helped beat down Bachmann's polling, revealing much of his radical and sometimes cruel policies related to bullying and her stance on cutting social security. This gaffe has accumulated the distrust of families across the nation, unsettled by Bachmann's blatant disregard for public health safety.

Likewise, independent voters have begun to break for the Landrieu campaign in even greater numbers, with polls showing the Vice president leading Bachmann by 15-20 points with independent voters. A disappointing sight for Republicans to witness as the Republican National Convention displayed possibly the highest amount of excitement ever before seen for a single candidate.

Assuming Bachmann can't gain ground with independents, it's unlikely she'll be able to offset those losses by breaking into much of the industrial Midwest since Vice President Landrieu's running mate, Sherrod Brown, has seemingly locked down blue-collar voters.

AP News: Will Huntsman's ties to China sink him?

By Rochelle Williams

Madison, Wisconsin — Among a primary filled with partisan grievances, political theater, and rhetoric stood the popular former Utah Governor, Jon Huntsman. The Democratic Party's nightmare was not an evangelical loon ready to ring the bells of social issues or even a Tea Party Huckster declaring war on government spending. The nuclear option was always Governor Huntsman, the moderate heartthrob.

The well-spoken Governor with a record without blemish, he exited the Republican convention with a decisive lead in most polls. Huntsman had honed in on the sluggish economy, vowing to bring economic opportunity back while slashing taxes for the lower and middle class. Democrats hoped the Governor's positions on social issues and immigration would generate criticism from his right flank, but their hopes fizzled as the GOP, driven by anti-Democrat hunger, rallied behind him anyway.

But the gloves came off when the conversation trailed off to China.

One of President Clark's late-term initiatives has been reinforcing American economic interests from the supposed "threat" China poses to American interests both at home and abroad. Democrats have begun to push emphasis on Huntsman's ties to the Huntsman Corporation, with some even labeling Huntsman "the candidate who will sell your jobs to China." Huntsman has pushed back on these claims, proclaiming he has no current ties to the corporation and would work to create new jobs for America's industrial heartland.

Vice President Landrieu has also taken this rhetoric in her attacks on Huntsman, hoping to claw her way up from the political quicksand that is the economy. However, some of Clark's initiatives to combat China have garnered criticism, like the advocacy for a Trans Pacific Partnership, a proposed trade agreement between 12 Pacific Rim economies: Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Singapore, Vietnam, and the United States. The proposal has hit the natural Democratic base of unions, unwilling to accept another free trade agreement without basic assurances that their jobs won't be affected.

The deal that President Clark has begun negotiations for presents a challenge to his Vice President's campaign, which has so far failed to reconnect with disillusioned workers and distance itself from unpopular trade policies.

The time for Landrieu to change course is fading rapidly, and her chances of carrying the Democratic torch another four years may just go up in smoke.
